text: the kids LOVE it but I didn't actually eat the food because I was too grossed out. really cute for kids though

Excellent deli food, great ice cream, and a crazy fun atmosphere.  It's definitely a place that needs to be seen to be understood.

The food itself is not extraordinary but quite good for the style.  There are other places I would recommend for "just food" in Madison, but the atmosphere and environment add so much to the experience.  I would recommend this as a place to check out for lunch, probably not dinner.  

The ice cream is also a great after-meal treat.  They come in a variety of great flavors.

You can skip this place. We thought this would be a fun place during a day trip to Madison, but it's just not worth it. The novelty items around the restaurant are broken, the food is overpriced and rather gross. I'm not sure how you mess up chicken strips, but my daughter said they tasted funny so she didn't eat them. She lives fries and didn't eat this either. The milk shake we ordered was itty bitty.  Perhaps, they should tell new customers it's a baby shake if you order one with a meal. The service was incredibly slow, yet it's a weekday on off peak hours. It shouldn't take 20 minutes for basically fast food, nor should I need to ask for extra napkins when food is set down and spilling. 
We tried to order ice cream to go and the guy in front of us ordered a double. I can't even imagine what a mini or single scoop looks like. Complete rip off and kids asked to go someplace else!

I give it 3 stars for a mix of food and atmosphere + merry-go-round outside.
Great place for young kids/toddlers, especially to ride the carousel.
I gave it 4 at first, but after reading what I wrote, 4 did not seem accurate.

When it comes to the food I can only comment on the entrees, not the desserts, which are clearly a whole other specialty of theirs, seems like they would be good, but also it seems like it's an either or situation, either a meal, or a big dessert.

If I go back, I'm honestly happy just having a burger and fries, good coffee shop/deli style burger and fries.

I fantasize that the corned beef or pastrami is awesome like the kind I can get in Chicago at Manny's, or what used to be Kaufman's, but the reality is quite different, for the price they should pile the cb or p on high, like real deli's in Chicago or NYC do, but noooooo! (as Belushi used to say). Skimpy, penny pinching, the pickles are good. The rye bread is not substantial enough, too crumbly, too weak. The cb and p is mediocre at best, weak flavor, not fatty enough, and I prefer lean, but this is too lean, it's not really good and certainly no where near great. A definite letdown.

So to sum it up, for Madison, for Wisconsin, I guess if you're desperate for a cb or p sandwich on rye with a pickle, in a "deli", then this is your ONLY choice. If you want to drive 3 hours to Chicago and go to Manny's you will know what a real CB or P sandwich is, and forever after will not settle for less, unless you deceive yourself and live in denial, or are stuck somewhere, wherein the choices are non-existent like Madison or Wisconsin in general.

Sigh, what's with the mediocre food in Wisconsin, sad.
Expensive.  Bland food.  Terrible service.  Loud atmosphere.  Three people on a Saturday afternoon ordering simple dishes took almost an hour.  I won't be going here again.

Sadly, Ella's Deli continues its decent towards total failure.
I decided to try the deli for the 12th time in the past year, and the quality of the place has dropped even lower than before. 

The prices have been hiked yet again, the portions
have shrunk again, the waitstaff has been reduced in number AGAIN, and the most upsetting thing that has happened to this once great deli is the fact the place is filthy. 

They really need to close for a good week and clean the place from top to bottom. Want to know how bad this once great Madison attraction has fallen? I saw a roach crawling around on floor. A freaking ROACH. As in the creepy crawly kind - not the Willy Street kind. :)

This makes me so sad as this place was once a true landmark for Madison. Now it is hanging on a thread - only getting by due to the animatronic toys and gadgets. If this were any other Resturant, it would have closed down years ago.

Sad.
Love this place! The nostalgia the food the service... Love love love. Summer time and the ice cream the carousel. Makes me so happy!!!

I stopped by here to eat before we went to see Marilyn Manson at the Orpheum and I was surprised how packed it was on a Tuesday afternoon.  Our waitress was friendly, food was delicious and hot, however it seemed to take forever to get refills or our food.

I would gladly come back, just hoping for a slightly better experience on my next go-around.

Ella's is always entertaining for the kids despite the fact that many of the "moving" toys on the ceiling and walls are broken. But what really turned me off were the prices.

A turkey rueben on average-sized bread with three or four slices of meat was $8.19. For $2.20 more you get a small pile of fries and shot glass full of coleslaw on the plate. A Mr. B Burger with a tablespoon of coleslaw and some special sauce on a soft onion bun was $6.20. It looked small and lonely without any fries and I couldn't keep from thinking that I could have gotten something similar at the BK down the road for a third of the price. With sundaes starting at $5.50 we packed up and headed elsewhere.

Epic fail. Overpriced, not even fair tasting food, lousy service.  If you want to pay $8 for a sandwich far worse than you can make at home using prepackaged deli meats from the grocery store then by all means, this is your place.  It may have been good once and they may have had pride in the "deli" aspect, but that has long since been abandoned for motorized gadgets attached to the ceiling and the carousel out front.  Kids may be amused by the place, but you will be annoyed when you (finally) get your food and then move closer to enraged when you see your bill.  Go to Chucky Cheese instead.

HUGE menu.  They have one ~20 page menu for food, and another entirely different menu for the ice cream, shakes, etc.

The main menu is primarily deli standards, so if you're looking to get a tongue sandwich on rye, here's the place.  But they also have burgers and other American food.

The main reason I go here is their Chicken Matzo Ball soup, which you can only get a couple other places in Madison.  Tasty, but I wish it had more chicken, it's usually just chicken dust.  Manna Cafe on Sherman Ave. has much better Chicken Matzo Ball soup with fresh veggies, lots of chicken and a side of fresh bread - but they only make it on Fridays currently, so I end up at Ella's usually.

Otherwise, barring their lunch specials, the place is really expensive for what you get.  $9 for salami on a toasted bagel with no sides?  It tasted great, but I can make that myself at home for $1.50, even using "artisan" salami.

Ella's is a great place for kids.  Tons of moving animated puppets and things flying around the ceilings (which are made by one of the owners).  Games that kids can play, and even some of the tables are interactive.  They also have a carousel open during the warm months.

You can also reserve the place for birthday parties, and they have a bunch of different packages depending on your budget.

Since it's such a kids kind of place, and you have all those things whirring around the restaurant, it's pretty noisy, even when almost empty.

3 stars for prices in relation to quality and amount of food for us adults, but a neat place for kids or people visiting Madison.

This place is a kid's dream! Tons of animated toys and terrific ice cream. We didn't have a meal, just dessert. For such a cheerful place all the staff looked pissed to be working. Maybe it is all the sensory overload? I like that the menu has a baby plate for kids 1 and under with a variety of soft foods. We'll definitely return on our next trip to Madison!

Perhaps I can help clarify the reasons one would eat at Ella's Deli.

Ella's is another Madison institution.  I used to go to the State St. location quite a lot in college.  It was laid out like a normal restaurant, *sans* toys hanging from every corner.  Funny story: before I knew better, I tried to order a BLT there.  That was the day I learned about what a kosher deli is.  Who says you don't learn anything useful in college?!

The last time we went to the east side location, it practically drove us insane.  Every object in the place is constantly spinning, moving, jumping, ringing, chirping, chiming. or otherwise distracting your attention the entire time you're there.  It NEVER EVER lets up for a second.

The food is completely average deli food.  Always has been.  Decently made, decent ingredients, absolutely nothing to write home about.  It is, however, massively over-priced for what it is.  Especially considering the sensory assault you have to endure while eating it, which just can't be good for the digestion.

IMHO, this place is a great place to take your kids.  They will have all kinds of weird stuff to watch, and it may even be distracting enough to get them off their game-boys for a minute.  hence the three-star rating, because there is at least this one reason to eat here.

Normal adults looking for normal food in a normal setting should avoid Ella's like the plague.  I hear Stalzy's is really good - I'll have to try them sometime soon!

It had been a couple of years since we took our children to Ella's and time has not improved things. It used to be a place with slightly overpriced but reasonable food and an interesting ambiance for the kids. The prices are still there but food quality, if our visit is any example, has dropped considerably. My son got a hamburger that was so small it couldn't be seen without opening the bun. It was over poked and dry as well. My reuben sandwich could be charitably described as a sauerkraut sandwich with a lot of russian dressing and just a hint of corned beef (less than two shavings thick). Soggy toasted bread rounded out the entree. My wife's 'superb owl' of soup was quite a large bowl on a very large platter containing about an inch of soup (The best of the three meals)!

It's too bad when such an effort is made seemingly to cut costs. I guess diners are noticing. Ella's used to have a line almost every day for lunch. Today (a Friday at 12:25pm) we we seated also immediately. What a shame that a Madison landmark I have dined at now and again for years has lost it's way. Too many other choices for the kids now. I will go elsewhere in the future.

The atmosphere is interesting, but the noise created by all the whirliegigs is as loud as a bar on Friday night.  The service was terrible, even for a sandwich place.  I was one of four tables, two tables per server.  She walked away as she spoke, she didn't refill water, and was pretty clueless when it came to the menu.  The food was meh at best.  I tried the Lox Salad.  Some lox, nicely flavored, accompanied by a handful of pathetic looking lettuce and a few spoon fulls of rice on an enormous plate for $10.  Presentation was clearly not a consideration.  I want to support local businesses but if given the choice between Ella's and a chain bagel shop, the chain would win hands down in overall experience, food quality, atmosphere, and service.

Just stopped by Ella's after going by there for years.  Was hoping for a better experience.  I paid $10 dollars for a roast beef sandwich with a small pickle Slice and shit glass of coleslaw.  The roast beef was so brown it looked very old with no taste.  I spend a lot of time and money eating out and probably would never go here or recommend to anyone.  Nothing like any deli I have ever been to and not worth the time or money.

I really wanted to like the place

While Ella's deli might not have some of the best food in town, it does have the electricity bill.  Therein lies the real reason you should visit, the explosion of gadgetry, mechanical toys, mouse-trap style novelties, and all around eye candy make Ella's the only restaurant I know of where its permissible to get up and wander around wide-eyed at this little shop of curiosities. 

If you have strong impulses towards cold-cuts, potato salad, reubens, and ice cream or a small convoy of children with frequently shifting attention spans Ella's will be perfect.

For those looking for a bit more culinary sophistication or higher quality shy away from the American foods and learn towards the more kosher elements.  The chicken in my Caesar salad was actually so stale it was send-back worthy.  But for a place with a carousal outside and an interior that's been as constant as bologna fallen behind the stove, Ella's makes for a nice one time excursion of new sights and sounds.

What could be more fun than Ella's?  The food is good too!

First time here after my daughter was diagnosed with Celiac and needs a strict gluten free diet.  They made her a sandwich on GF bread.  Sh ordered mashed potatoes as her side and the waiter came back with the ingredients from the mashed potatoes to make sure it was ok!   So great!

I have mixed feelings about this place. Some of the food is excellent; the soups, the salads, the ice cream, and it's a fun atmosphere for kids, but I wish it were a little cleaner, and sometimes the food isn't delivered as described on the menu, and it was a little weird to go to the checkout with my un-totaled tab to have the host ask me what I wanted to tip. Well, they hadn't given me a totaled tab at the table, or shown me the itemized receipt so I could a) check to see if it was correct, and b) calculate the tip.
Great atmosphere for kids and great menu for vegetarians.  Lots to see, great service.
Bad food, overpriced, bad service. And this was at 3 in the afternoon when it was dead. Don't waste your time.

We stopped in at 1:00PM on a Saturday with our two grandchildren.   After waiting to be seated, we ended up waiting 45 minutes for our food. For a while, the children were entertained by all the decor, but got antsy before too long.  The food was not quite as good as Culver's (but twice as expensive), the burgers were overcooked, fries were bland.   Nothing was very hot.     

We mentioned the wait to the waitress who had nothing in particular to say about it, other than they were busy.  We then mentioned it to the manager, who just said "sorry".   Frustrating experience.    We won't return.

Ella's is a great place for kids. Great decor and they even have a carousel! The food is pretty good, not amazing. Often loud and crowded. I would recommend the Reuben or the matzo ball soup. I love the strawberry cheesecake ice cream. - chocolate shoppe??? 3 for adults. 5 for children.

The other day I walked in with the hopes of walking out with an amazing Reuben sandwich. Instead I walked in to a sad-looking group of employees in the kitchen. I asked where do I order food? They weren't very busy looking at all, so I was confused. Each person bounced me around until I decided to just leave, and in summary never will I return...even when my  daughter is of age to ride their creepy looking merry-go-round & their lack of desire to take an order (over $20) made me lose my appetite. I took my business elsewhere.
Fun place for families,  my salami was tough, the bread was a bit stale. Slow service too

Many fond memories of taking our young children to Ella's a generation ago. Today we took our young grandchildren there for a special treat. Abysmal. Dirty. Slow service. Stale bread. Burned hamburger. Cold hotdog. Not good.

Don't get me wrong, I used to like Ella's and I think their premise is unique and awesome but if only their food and desserts could match the atmosphere....

The last time I was there, I took my out of town parents there for dessert. After perusing the sticky menu binder (seriously, why is the menu a binder?), the unfriendly waiter took our order. Black & white delight sundae for me, root beer float for mom, and can't remember what dad ordered.  Everything was just.....meh.  Seems like Ella's is simply resting on their laurels. Maybe they could take some pointers from other ice cream parlors such as Fenton's Creamery in Oakland, CA where the food is good, ice cream is delicious, and there are lines out the door.  

Sorry but now when I think of getting ice cream, I don't think of going to Ella's.  I instead think of the Chocolate Shoppe or maybe even Michael's. If they gave the place a hose down, dusted off some of the kitschy mechanical's, and slimmed down the menu a bit, Ella's might be able to compete with other establishments who are just doing it better.

Everyone, more especially kids, will enjoy this restaurant.  Antique mechanical games abound, including figures moving across the ceiling.  Some tables have games under a glass top that customers can play.

Food is excellent, especially the baked potatoes, matzo ball soup, and sandwiches.  Prices are reasonable.   Rstaurant is packed at lunch and dinner.

Other than in wintertime, a full-sized carousel operates outside.

The atmosphere here is the first thing you notice. It's definitely more suited for kids, but it can be fun for adults as well. 
The food is typical diner/American food, which means it's fatty and greasy and ha peavy, so if that's what you're feeling, then this place fits. The desserts are decent as well, but the food here is not great enough for us to come back or crave.

Revising my previous review. Last year, went Ella's twice and the service was very poor to say the least.

Today, we went back to at least soak up the atmosphere with a few kids who hadn't been there before. We had Gregory as our waiter, and, based on Gregory, the consensus for Ella's went from one star to five stars. I hope Gregory and his light, fun attitude is what pervades the rest of the wait staff. People go to Ella's to have fun, and their server is at least 50% of the equation -- they don't have to be comedians, just be friendly, courteous, and attentive -- Gregory was all those things. The food was good, and we got it quick. Definitely a good night.

We went here on a recent visit to Madison with our kids after riding the Polar Express train.  If you're not a fan of clowns and circus stuff surounding you at every turn, don't go here.  If you are looking for outstanding food, don't go here either.  After paging through the 30 page binder they call their menu, our table had a Chicago style hot dog, meatloaf and mashed potatoes, a cheeseburger, a reuben sandwich and some soup.......  We all said the same thing after we left, "well that was a disappointment".

The kids really enjoyed themselves and ate most of their chicken tenders, I guess I haven't indoctrinated them enough yet into the belief that clowns and circus memorabilia  is evil.  Seriously, this may be a good place for desert and a quick look with the kids.  If you are looking for a great meal, keep looking.

If you go here for entertainment and ice cream (Chocolate Shoppe brand), you'll be satisfied. My daughter loved all the fun things spinning around the ceiling, and of course, the carousel outside ($1.50/ride, adults are free to join). Although they have a large menu, the food is expensive and mediocre at best. Reminds me of fair/event/concession stand food. So eat lunch elsewhere and then come here for dessert and some fun.

This is our 5th trip to this restaurant... if I could rate it a zero.. I would.   Each trip it has gone down hill. 

Nothing in our party of 9's food was good. The pasta was ice cold when it came, our rubens were Soggy and had barely any meat... it cost $14 for them with fries.. yes.. $14 each!! To add fries ot was $4.... for a very small amount of fries. 

Our daughter had the kids fish and fries... they are overlooked and in the shape of fish... (the inside did not resemble fish at all). 

A child a few booths down started vomiting, there were so many people touching the table and continuing to serve food.. I would not be surprised if there is an outbreak. 

We also ended the trip with ice cream. Our daughter ordered a $6.60 cherry ice cream soda as I watched them make it, it was spilling all over the counter and see them use different rags and touch the cup and spoon on the counter.. it was so gross. The drink tasted disgusting.. it appeared like she had no idea how to make it.. and it tasted the same. 

Save yourselves a trip, the atmosphere is cute.. but the food is over priced and not worth it.

What has happened to this place???  So loud all 4 adults left with blinding headaches.  Dirty dishes thrown - literally thrown- into bus tubs by wait staff made us jump every few minutes...we thought someone had dropped a tray full  of food on the floor.  We could not even talk to each other, way too loud. Service agonizingly slow.  When i got up and asked our server how much longer, she said it's coming up now.  I said " no,  it's been up for 15 minutes, actually" as we could see it.  The food is good, but prices really are high by anyone's standards.  Madison has plenty of great places to eat.  If you feel that your kids need this kind of over - stimulation, you need parenting lessons.

Horrible service, there was a kid working that looked about 13 years old. All the staff stands around talking and yapping. There is a sink full of ice that they go and dip their hands in without gloves and then fills the drinks up with ice.  The carousel operator watches his phone instead of the kids that are riding the ride. Asked for two banana splits and they didn't know how to make it... And that was 16 dollars. Never going here again!

I'm only giving this place two stars for two reasons.   The first being the look of absolute wonderment on my son's face when we walked through the door.  He didn't know where to look.  The second would be because they are the only restaurant I've ever been to that offers a baby plate.  My daughter loved that even though when the menu says "small amounts," it is entirely accurate.   

Now the bad,  which I never saw on any "Things to do in Madison" when I was researching the town in preparation of our move there.  I keep telling myself our waitress was just new,  as she seemed to be running constantly and assumed we only wanted drinks.   When my root beer float exploded all over the table,  I tried to mop it with the two napkins we received.   This didn't do the job,  so I waited calmly for the waitress to come back for our food order.  When she showed up, she ignored the mess and tried to flit away after hearing our drinks were good.  She didn't know the menu items and was unable to answer questions I had, but grabbed me a few more napkins so I could clean the mess up.  Food ordered, table sticky.  My three year old announces he has to pee,  which is bad since my husband took the oldest to the game shop, and I have the baby and the three year old by myself.   Our waitress figured out we hadn't left since she dropped the soup off and retreated before I could reach the table.   I had to retrive my son from the bathroom, and while making my way back to the table,  I notice a fella getting ready to bus the table, despite my bag sitting on it.   My soup in his hands, almost in the pan.  Should have let him take it.  The rest of the food took a while,  so we entertained ourselves playing the game that was part of the very sticky table... why didn't I let that fella bus the table?  Food arrives!   My daughter loved her baby plate, my son promptly dropped his corn dog on the floor, and I questioned the integrity of my meatloaf.  I know,  meatloaf is one of those hit or miss items.   In this case,  all the food (except the baby plate) looked like some one ran down to the local discount grocery store,  grabbed a few frozen dinners, heated them,  and served them at twice the price.  Blech!  The ice cream was nothing to write home about and for the cost of mine alone,  I could have gotten a pint of Ben and Jerry's.

Overall, not worth the time, money, or energy.   I may take the kids to ride the carrousel but honestly,  I've seen cleaner ones at county fairs.

I eat here usually with out-of-town guests who I want to have an interesting experience. And it never fails to disappoint. While the atmosphere is certainly unique, the place never seems clean, service is spotty at best and the food is generally below par, at best.

Most recent visit, I ordered a hot dog. I received a decent sized frank, but the bun was huge, way too big for the hot dog. Worst of all the bun was very, very stale. The dog itself wasn't great. Others at my table had similar disappointments. Thinking to the 8-10 times I have been to Ella's, the food pretty much stinks consistently. The only exception for me is the matzo ball soup, but even that seems watered down. Our server was ditzy and service was not fast by any means.

If you want a unique experience, this is a good choice. If good food is your goal, go elsewhere.

AWFUL PLACE. The French toast they tout as indescribable can't be described on the menu because the word they'd have to use is "inedible"-- it was dry and flavorless. The noise level due to some stupid overhead maze using billiard balls is similar to being in a bowling alley. The coffee tastes like dishwater and the server was disinterested at best--just dropped off our coffee and walked away. My husband had to go to the busing station to find the Splenda. This was our first and only visit.
Super fun place to take the kids. Go for the ambiance, stay for the indigestion. Great ice cream and, seriously satisfactory food. We had a great time on the old carousel, as well.

I came with a friend for dinner on a Friday night. The crazy ambiance was a complete surprise - moving toys all over the ceiling, themed shadowbox tables with moving parts inside, a functional deli counter, oldtimey candy like Orange Crush licorice for sale at the cash register. We were seated immediately and the waitress answered our questions about the menu. 

I had the open face Rueben sizzler (dresssing on the side) and loved it. The fries were great (I added salt and vinegar) as was the cole slaw. My friend had the lox platter with fries. We sat there for three hours talking and never felt a bit rushed by the wait staff. Our drinks were refilled as needed. We were too full to try the desserts, although I was intrigued by the pickle sundae!

I would love to come here again.

We stop with the kids whenever we get in the area. The food is good and the kids love the ambiance with all the animation. Unlike what others have said we have found the staff to be nice and honest hard workers. As far as the best midwest Ruben it's pretty darn good.

On a trip through Madison, my family stopped at this quaint restaurant based on a recommendation. First impression - cute, unique, noisy, busy, needed a little TLC, and an ADHD nightmare. We were seated at a table and a waitress showed up maybe ten minutes later. She took our order, brought our drinks, and after 40 minutes we asked when we might get our food. Her response, "I couldn't begin to guess how long it will be." There was no assurance that she would check on it - it would come when it was set out by the cook. Great. Ten minutes go by and we see that the waitress has picked up plates that look like our order which has been sitting on the counter a little while. Of the three meals ordered, one was fine, another clearly had been sitting for a while and the bread on a sandwich had become a bit soggy, and the last, a cheeseburger, was extremely well done with much crunch at each bite. This especially was not going to work for us. We called the waitress over, explained the situation and asked for a new one. We asked if this could be made quickly as we'd already waited 40+ minutes for the meal delivered. She said she'd put the order in, but she didn't know how long it would take due to the orders ahead of us. Not a good answer. We asked for the manager, and explained the situation to her. She assures us she'll take care of it and will get it expedited. Twenty minutes later, we STILL did not have our food. That's it. We were done. We paid for the food eaten and left. 

I will never recommend this restaurant to anyone. It's a shame that customer service means absolutely nothing to them.

Oh please! Other than the desserts, which often come with dirty silverware, it's simply not worth it. The place is jam stuffed with toys, one would think at first glance, that it would be a mini paradise. Upon closer look, everything is filthy and dusty. The floors and tables are sticky. The prices are inflated and the waitstaff only occassionally friendly. I love good Jewish food. Ella's is not. The matzoh ball soup has no flavor and the blintzes are soggy. The sandwich meats are processed and the bread is dry. I would come for their famous #1 if I had to have a sugar fix, but it is most certainly not like the Ella's deli I remember on State Street from the late 1970's.

A place to bring the youth. Or be reminded of your own.  Amazing stuff in here.  You could look around for hours at all the stuff.  But you won't, because at least at lunch time, this place is crowded and so you better stay seated or else be in the way of servers or bussers.  
Paid over 80 dollars for 4 small adult lunches and 1 child.  Over priced much!? 
My MIL had a hair in her matzo (sp?) ball soup.  My husband liked the turkey on his sandwich and my grilled cheese with pepper jack was good.  We ordered a black and white split thinking it was a banana split with choc and vanilla ice cream but nope, there was no banana, just ice cream LOL ok.  
Husband said the men's bathroom reeked of smoke.  The women's did not but was so small only 2 stalls for a huge, kid's restaurant what?!?
Carousel was carousel-ey.  My baby wasn't impressed but my 4 year old niece loved it.  Only a buck to ride.  Next time we will probably just come for ice cream, skip the actual meals here.
(the greatest coffee shop MOKA is next door fyi, other sleepy parents)

My wife grew up in Madison and spent her childhood going to Ella's Deli. Unfortunately times have not been kind to Ella's Deli. I first went 12 years ago with her family on my first visit to Madison and the food was good and the prices reasonable. A bowl of Matzo ball soup had two Matzo balls and came in an actual bowl. We have gone to Ella's on every trip that we make to Madison but have noticed that over the years it has become a disappointing experience. The food has become mediocre yet the prices have risen, which is quite an odd phenomenon. Usually prices increase with quality but Ella's has managed to rewrite the rules. A bowl of Matzo ball soup is now one ball in a cup, yet more expensive. A $9 Reuben does not even include fries and somehow a scoop of ice cream is a whopping $3.65. This was our last visit to this once good and reasonable but now expensive and less satisfactory restaurant. This ends 12 years of my visiting and a lifetime for my wife.
Terrible. Food and service were awful. Avoid at all costs. Overpriced, we waited for an hour to get our food, and when we did the bagel was hard, pastrami dry. Just...stay away

The food is 3 star, the decor is 5. This is an amazing place to take children for ice cream! The menu is all bland and way over priced for what it is. But the tables are fun, the ceiling is a sensory overload, and the carousel is amazingly fun for cheap. I will always love this place!

Fun and delicious in the summer; Cold and miserable in the winter.  

I had had the Mediterranean burger (a nice number with feta cheese and some lovely oil-based dressing for dipping or drizzling) back in the summer and have had dreams about it where I have awoken with a drool-drenched pillow ever since.  I'm sure you can imagine I was quite excited to be reunited with this special burger (a fresh one...not the one I'd already eaten on Memorial Day) when we 
went again in early January.

Well, it was not to be so.  The burger was fine.  The dressing was fine.  The problem was the four to five crumbs of feta on the burger.  They charged us when we asked for more.

But by far the worst thing about our most recent visit was the fact that there was no way in Hell the thermostat was set anywhere above the low 60s.

I run cold naturally so at first thought it was just me, but I looked around and the two other parties in the place were wearing their coats while eating!  My boyfriend who runs hot also kept his coat on throughout lunch (something i have never seen him do.). 

We even switched tables from one by the window to one in the interior of the place hoping, at first, we were just by a drafty window.  We were wrong.

We ate our mediocre sandwiches fantasizing about the hot chocolates and lattes we were going to get from Moka next store after our arctic lunch was over.

It wasn't all bad, though.  My five-year old had some Chocolate Shop ice cream to top off the meal (he was too distracted by the displays to notice hypothermia was setting in) and waitstaff was pleasant and attentive.  

I am doling out only two stars because if you can't afford to keep your heat on during winter maybe you should shut down in winter just like your carousel.

Loved all the cool toys moving around and that we could play with the table.  However the two sandwiches took close to an hour to get and were just ok.  Also the table and menu both felt grimy. If you don't like kids I'd avoid this place.  It was packed full of screaming little kids.

10.99 for a baked potato!!!!!!

First I asked what soup has more vegetables, the matzo ball or chicken noodle. The waitress says they are the same. I get the soup and there are no vegetables besides a very minuscule amount of carrots. Waitress should have advised me of that. The big bowl of soup only had 1 matzo ball in it too so I needed to order more food. The waitress had taken away my menu so I just ordered a baked potato without knowing the price. I asked if I ordered cheddar cheese if it would be shredded cheddar or the melted nacho style cheese. She said that she thought it was shredded. I get it and it's the gross melted cheese. I'm on my lunch break so whatever I eat it and just try to take off most of the cheese. I get the bill and its $18!!!!! For chicken broth, 1 matzo ball, and a baked potato with gross cheese, broccoli, and chopped tomatoes. Not to mention the slow service.

Ugh never ever coming back. Save your money and time and go somewhere else like Crostini. 

Note for server: if you don't know, then ask the kitchen. Don't just guess. Also advise someone on the absurd price of the baked potato if they are ordering it without a menu in front of them. 

If I didn't have to rush back to work, I would have asked to speak to a manager.

This place is pretty overpriced. The decor is a bit creepy, but the kids were entertained; I just hope they don't have night terrors now. 

I got a small bowl of soup and just one soup of ice cream and the bill was ten bucks after tip. I suppose I've wasted money in worse ways, but I probably wouldn't come back.

I was so disgusted by the food at Ella's that I decided to finally create a yelp account. I've been here a few times because it's popular with the kids, and the service has always been fine. The surroundings are also impressive, but this is a restaurant and the food has to be eaten at some point.

The food served here is so bad as to feel insulting.

* * * This review is based on Ice Cream & Merry-Go-Round visits Only * * *

My daughter and I came here yesterday (after a long ordeal up the block from here) for waffle cones.  Black cherry for her, Mint Chip for me.  

I took my 11 year old 2nd cousin here for ice cream and a horsey-ride about a month ago.

The place is pretty cool eye candy for out of towners; I agree with Nina O. though they ought to shut the place down for a day, cover tables, counters, kitchen, etc. and take a huge can of compressed air and blow the years of dust off of everything in the place.

Bottom line? Great for kids. Hell on earth for those without. 

The prices weren't great - $6 for an ice cream sundae? - but the ice cream was good, and the options are many. They have a whole desserts-only menu, for Pete's sake. 

The serving dishes are just small enough that if the ice cream melts at all, there's an overflow - but that's just incentive to eat faster, right? 

I've never been when the place isn't packed, but with a real merry-go-round in use, it's not surprising.

I have been coming here since I was a pint sized tot. It's your average run of the mill deli style menu but the atmosphere is amazing and makes for a wonderland of excitement for little kids. I'm still in awe of all the moving gadgets when I go in. The carousel is beautiful and needless to say I myself have ridden it countless times... I luv Ella's!

Ok, I am totally charmed by this place. It's kitschy and loud and the food is awesome deep fried deliciousness. Love the old animatronic crap that is everywhere!

Best of all, however, are the absolutely AMAZING and gloriously perfect deep fried pickles. I've yet to find them done better ANYWHERE.

Why are you closing, Ella's?! Ella's is the most amazing place. Of all of the places I've been (and that's a LOT), Ella's was the most enchanting, fun, wonderous, and magical. I told everyone that told me they were going to Wisconsin to go there. There is nothing like it anywhere. Who cares if the soup wasn't great? THAT WASN'T THE POINT. First, you should have had the ice cream, second, the sandwiches were great. Most importantly, Ella's was a treasure and it was lucky for all of us to have seen it without paying admission.

Although the decor was intersting,and out of place! It seems like something that should be in Wisconsin Dells/ Baraboo! Right next to Paul Bunions another distasteful tourist trap ! We sat down in this loud dirty dinning establishment,and got a filthy binder full of like 100 food items ? I knew we stepped in to a quantity not quality restaurant ! The prices where really high $2.95 for a dill pickle fries $5 crazy. I see by the 100,000, million kilowatts they are burning per hour is why the high prices. We ordered a soda got bill and left ! We only waited 10 min up front to pay! Service is poor and pushy.What does a Circus cluttered distasteful decor have to do do with Jewish, Russian American cuisine anyway? If you like high prices, screaming kids, crowds? poor food quality and lots of quantity this place is for you! Bring $50 with for lunch it will cost a couple just that !

I has the Reuben today. I was very disappointed.  For a 10.00 sandwich is was sad. It came with the smallest dish of cole slaw, the bread was terrible thin and dry. Toast not grilled. The sandwich was so thin. There was 3 slices of meat. My friends was the same.  For a deli Reuben this was terrible.  The sandwich was no more than 2 inches thick, soggy and mostly sauerkraut. The sauerkraut juice literally ran out of it.
The kids meal came with a small cup of applesauce.  There was about 1/2 teaspoon of applesauce in it. It was so small you could not get a spoon in it. It was smaller than A 30 cc medicine cup. For shame.
Won't go back

.
Perfect place if you have kids.  Lots of visual stimulation...plus ice cream.  Food wasn't bad either.

There's absolutely no other restaurant like this, ever.  You wouldn't know what I mean unless you've been there.  The atmosphere is almost that of a bad dream or what I'd imagine a bad trip on drugs would be.  Clowns, circus people, etc hanging from the walls that move across the ceiling.  Feet with faces on them, strange decor all around.  Even the tables have a little  display underneath a seethrow plastic setting.  I bet back in the 80's this place was fun and great for kids, but now it's just rather creepy.  The menu is like 50 pages of word art, confusing and strange.  They have odd things on the menu like Lox and they don't have bacon or sausage or any pork products - I believe it's a Jewish owner.  Either way, this place is incredibly creepy but none-the-less the food was good and so was the service.

This is a sad place. It has a carousel, it has all sorts of cute kitsch scattered about, above, around, and beyond. It's got cartoon characters, horsies, and things that look like it came out of a child's dream... 

Unfortunately, this place is more of an adults nightmare. In fact, it's really only good for those who know no better, or don't care to get ripped off. The prices are unconscionably high for the mediocre quality and the skimpy servings (sides are extra, unless you settle for watered down cole slaw). There's a place in Chicago called Perry's, whose sandwiches are probably 4 times the size of those at Ella's, 10 times the quality, enough for two to share - maybe more... but at the same price. How is that possible? 

Ella's is also dirty. Dirty seats, dirty tables, dirty silverware, dirty plates, dirty cups... If you are going to slip that much money out my pocket, keep the damn place clean. The servers are kinda not so clean either. My son and I waited almost 10 minutes to be served after being seated. We only got attention after I flagged down a server from another section who passed by and made a conscientious effort to avoid eye contact. Really? I would have left, but my son would have been sad. Instead, I let him enjoy and decided to be the sad one.

It's possible only because they surround themselves with a carousel, kitsch about, above, around, and beyond. The kids want to go there... they don't care about an overpriced sorry sandwich. They are too young and too distracted - and can you blame them? I don't. I blame the owners of Ella's for using all the distractions... because if your kids didn't want to go there, you probably wouldn't even bother either .

If you find that you simply MUST go here despite knowing in advance that the food is at best edible, at worst horrid and overpriced, and that the crap hanging from the ceilings is never cleaned although it zips mightily across the ceiling hovering over your plates, then there's nothing I can tell you to change your mind, is there??

The pound cake sundae is literally the only saving grace for this decrepit place.  You have been warned.
Watched with longing eyes as others were getting placemats and full sets of silverware as I'm sitting here with just a fork, warm lemonade, and soggy microwaved cheese fries. Not a happy camper.

I am a little torn on how to rate this place like other reviews. This place is a must see for kids at least once. The place is unique with all of the crazy decorations and toys hanging around. From our kid's point of view,  it is definitely 5 stars. For my wife and I, a would only say 3 stars.  They have a very large selection on their menu and the ice cream/shakes are delicious. It is a little over priced, but I think it's is because of the experience. The food is nothing special or out of the ordinary. I remember going to this place when I was in high school and loved it, but now that I'm older, I'm like,  "Eh... its ok".

I went back to Ella's and they impressed me enough to edit my review and give them another star.  I still feel the majority of the food is overpriced, especially considering what you get for it, but it tasted good and was fresh.  Kosher isn't important to me but for those of you who it is this place will fill your need.  The ice cream was still very tasty as was their homemade chocolate lava cake which was delicious.  It's still a little too kitschy for my personal taste so I don't see myself frequented the place but the occasional meal might be fun.  One thing that kept me from moving them up to four stars was the service.  They seem to staff a lot of kids still in school for whom it seems like this might be their first service job, our server didn't have an attitude problem or anything like that he was just very forgetful.
Oh and they ran out of tuna.  WTF!

Open faced roast beef on rye with mashed potatoes was stellar! Try the Big Red; It's a drink that comes with a large hunk of cotton candy on top. Kids who spend their birthday here get a balloon, free sundae, candy, and a free ride on the carousel. This place will keep your kids busy looking and pointing for hours! They will absolutely love it. They have a kosher deli, ice cream parlor, sit down restaurant area, candy shop,  and an outdoor carousel. So great! We've gone with groups of kids and worth adults! Everyone always has fun.

I could tell that this place was different, just pulling up to the parking lot. I've attached a photo and a link to their web site... but this is one of those cases where you just have to experience it to understand it. The web site doesn't even come CLOSE to conveying the experience that this small, family-oriented establishment is. And the best part of all... it was PACKED! And it was LOUD! (so be forewarned: this is for kids and those young at heart. it's not for those trying to be cool or hip.)

The menu is adorable, homey, features local menu items, and is reminiscent of a diner menu. But the really amazing part about this unique eatery are the gadgets, toys, and displays covering every square inch of the interior... and a working carousel outside to boot. There are a number of flying figures inside, including Bart Simpson, Batman, and Harry Potter. There is something interesting and unique inside every table. We sat at an electric toy-train table where the train actually moved. We also saw Monopoly embedded in another table, a display of PEZ dispensers in another, and a giant castle scene in another. Basically, this place is a child's toy fantasy come true.

A place where the families of Madison can have a good meal at a good price, and their kids can enjoy the near-chaos of every imaginable toy, gadget and doodad constantly in motion. A sensory overload experience!

I'm giving it four stars instead of five because it did seem like it could use an overall sprucing up. (My visit here was July 2006.)

I want Ella's to be better. But the food is only okay and the service is slow. The food is overpriced and not that special (except the fried pickles -- those were great).

I do question the judgment of people who think that Ella's is going to be a quiet place for dinner, though. Seriously? Could you not tell from the carousel outside that it's not good for meetings? 

By all means, bring kids here. It's a great place for them to look around and be entertained. And my husband loves the grilled pound cake. But it seems cramped, dirty and in dire need of an overhaul. I'd love to see them close down over the winter and completely update the inside and the menu.

If I were 4 years old this place would be awesome.  However I am a mom with two small children.   The atmosphere was relaxed which was what we were looking for.  The moving toys everywhere were fun to look at at first but then were just annoying and squeaky.  My 2 year old freak at one of the toys on a swing and my husband had to hold her the whole time.  
The deli is FILTHY.  Everything from the table to the chairs to the highchairs.  Disgusting.  I wanted to scrub my kids down when we left.  Just moving my chair I grabbed onto God knows what on the back of my seat.   Gross. 
The food was just as bad.  We both ordered burgers.  They were so overcooked they tasted burnt and they was no juice left in them.   They came out dry.  No toppings whatsoever.  Our waitress was just as bad.  She would drop things at our table and turn to run before we could even ask for anything else.  I watched one of the hostesses pick up a booster chair and examine it and brush dirt off of it before taking it to a table.  

We skipped dessert being anxious to leave and let our daughter ride the carousel (once again, filthy).  We will not return here nor recommend it.  We can't believe The Travel Channel even stopped in here.  Terrible.

I would rate this lower, but for what the food lacks, the atmosphere makes up. The food is best described as cafeteria. But the decor is insane! Be prepared to wait for a table. Kids and grown ups alike will enjoy all there is to see here. Loads of gadgets, robots, and such to look at. Worth a stoping in at least once. In the warmer months, you can take a ride on the carousel out front.

Super fun place for kids if you are anywhere near the Madison area. The decor alone replaced any need for bringing out electronic devices. The food is fine.. What you would expect to find in most of Wisconsin. I had he matzo bowl soup which I liked. My husband ordered some sort of veggie burger sandwich which was really awful. Kids were delighted with their cheeseburgers and fries. Awesome selection of delicious ice creams. End your meal with a carousal ride!

You know the scene in Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas where he has a terrible trip at Circus Circus? Yeah. This is worse. I always thought it looked like a wonderland driving by but when my fiance and I finally stopped in.. We realized we made a terrible mistake. That place is the stuff of nightmares. I had a nightmare that night. What may be whimsical for kids and weird adults is what horror movies are made of. We stayed and figured maybe the food is at least good. Not the case. I got the blintz and couldn't eat more than one of them. They came with what tastes like cherry pie filling and the middle was filled with what I'll assume is cottage cheese which made me gag. Coffee is worse than usual diner coffee.. For the prices they charge you would assume the food would be better or would come with sides. Come once and order ice cream or anything they don't actually make and that one time will be more than enough. To restock your nightmare fuel.

The atmosphere is really cool but the food is the problem. I got their classic corn beef sandwich. It was a $10 sandwich and it didn't come with fries. When it came out it was a puny little sandwich. Like something I would make at home. It just wasn't good. I really wanted to like it but I just couldnt.

The restaurant was dirty.  The wait staff served us a glass with mustard smeared on it.  Staff seemed annoyed to be there.  The food was OK.  a burger with cold rubbery cheese on a great bun.  A order of tasteless fries with a few still frozen.  Yes frozen and cold. A sunder that was $7.00 was not as good as it used to be with under grilled pound cake and a regular hot fudge sundae. I also noted that the sundea was listed 2x on the menu with slightly different names.  When I asked the server what was different about the 2 sundaes she told me nothing it's the same thing.  Not a fan of this.  The carousel is in need of repair and paint job.  This is a signature piece of the restaurant and is looking poor.  Overall, over priced, misleading and not well kept restaurant

Pricey!!!  Worst value in Madison.  Top end prices for small meals made from mediocre ingredients.  $14 for a reuben that was tiny and about 20 crinkle fries. $6+ for a kids meal with no drink or dessert.  Party of 7, at best one person claimed there food good.  

Gets 2 stars as the service was decent & atmosphere is unique.  

Money trap, try to avoid!

An ice cream parlour with a carousel?!!?  The ice cream is great in that old timey, not mashed with all the toppings sorta way.  The ice cream is great, but how do you fudge up ice cream?  The real treat is the setting which is so much fun.  Obviously it's ideal for children which for a person without kids means you have to deal with a least one child screaming for ice cream all the time.  I've never tried the deli menu, but I'd like to!
Absolutely horrible. Terrible food and worse. service. Overpriced and under-managed. Don't waste your time. I had high hopes which made the disappointment even harder to stomach. I will NEVER return.

This resturant is good for one thing: birth control. 

The food is gross and WAY overpriced. 

If you love screaming infants and paying ten dollars for a hot dog, this might just be your place.
Best place ever!!! I am so coming back again! Food us delicious, service is good, and there is a carousel! Amazing decorations too!

If you are going for viewing pleasure or dessert, PERFECT!  If you are going for an actual meal...don't.  The kids love this place, but they are also eating grilled cheese or chicken strips, hard to screw up.  The "adult" food is bland at best.  
Fun tables, fun views, and the merry-go-round is a plus, but just go for snacks.

Ella's is easily the Happiest Place On Earth!

I passed through Madison on my way up north and just had to stop here. This place was filled with the majest of a 1980's childhood, a real-life Pee Wee's Playhouse. 

The outside boasts in bright colors, a blue and white Vaudevillian awning and a large, working carousel out front. Inside, it's even better. The ceilings are lined with dozens of homemade paper-mâché figures that move. Yes, they are animatronic!  Characters range from the Beatles to Bart Simpson. All of the tables are display cases with clear tops containing everything from a Pez collection to a Wooly Willy Magnetic Face that you can play with while you wait for food.

After you're done gawking, you'll remember that you were here to eat...

Ella's menu is a whopping TWENTY pages with every kind of sandwich, side, and sausage imaginable. A separate SIX page menu is available for desserts, ice cream and milkshakes. They also have an entire two pages of vegetarian options, including soup.

I ordered:

- Kugel ( egg noodles, farmers' cheese, sour cream and cinnamon; served with a side of strawberries and sour cream)
- Reuben sandwich
- potato salad (the world's best!)
- cole slaw
- chocolate phosphate soda
- Turtle pound cake sundae (a big pile of fudgey, carmel, gooey yum!)

Ella's served up some of the most delicious food that has ever impressed my palate! It was so good that on my return trip, I went an hour out of the way to eat lunch here again. 

The food is a bit pricey, about $25 for appetizer, sandwich, and dessert. The portions are generous; but don't expect to get an overflowing platter. Ella's is good with following serving sizes. Restaurant was clean, servers were attentive and friendly.

Ella's satisfied not only my tastes but my imagination. This is a wonderful place for adults to reminisce and enjoy a fantastic meal.

As many reviewers have noted the food at Ella's is both substandard and expensive. It seems to be getting worse; the corned beef and pastrami are dry and tasteless, and tonight my dining companion's omelette and my kugel were both brought to the table cold. The server was friendly but forgot my fork, there was no salt or pepper on the table, and she thought that lox was "raw salmon." This once upon a time was a decent deli by midwestern standards, but the only reason to go there now is with some little kids to enjoy the ice cream, the carousel, and the manic cartoon atmosphere.
The food is good/ok as well as the service.  The four stars are because it is a great place to bring a kid.  The atmosphere and decorations are terrific for a young one.

"If my thumbs could grow there'd be two holes in the ceiling right now" - my son

Cool atmosphere with the bonus that what's sensory overload for adults is just enough to keep the kids occupied. Food's not bad either.

Astounding. It's like the circus over lunch. A million moving things for the kids to see including real rideable carousel. And perfectly good deli food, including plenty of vegetarian options. Feels world-historic.

Also don't want to go here if you have epilepsy, because the chaotic hodgepodge of dolls, toys, signs and flashing lights might induce a seizure.  However, even in its craziness, for a west coast jewish boy, this place was a savior for supplying me with some of the only New York deli-style sandwiches and salads in Wisconsin.  They also have great burgers.  Definitely gets 5 stars for the effort at creating a one-of-a-kind experience blending Wisconsin and Jewish cultures with an acid-trip circus, all rolled into one motif.

My last and final trip: Counted 3 house centipedes crawl across the floor, food was stale (all the breads and buns), and the service was super slow. Not to sound harsh but I am surprised this place passes any sort of food and bug inspection each year. I don't know if there is some leeway with inspections because it's an age old Madison delicacy or what, but this resturaunt needs to be closed down. I'm sure they had a good run but please, don't take your children or family here. There are much healthier and more sanitary resturaunts to dine at. AVOID.

Literally the scariest place I have ever been.
I have no idea how people think this place is suitable for children because I'm an adult and I was uncomfortable.
Aside from the creepy atmosphere, I didn't find the food too appealing either. I got a grilled chicken with tomato + lettuce on whole wheat. The chicken was a little cold and the bread was toasted despite the fact that I asked them not to do so. Service was meh. Nothing out of the ordinary but not terrible either. In any case, I really don't understand how this place as survived as long as it has.

I can't rate the food since I never ate. My friend wanted to show me this place since she used to live in Madison and thought I might like to bring my kids to this fun themed deli/ice cream restaurant. We arrived around noonish for lunch on Friday Feb. 10th.  We had 3 in our party. The hostess on duty quickly sat us at a table.  My friend very kindly asked of we could please sit at a booth.  The hostess told her no and said there were no booths in our area.  My friend said, "Perhaps we could be seated in a booth over in that area" and the hostess looked up and said "No" in a very annoyed sounding tone.  My friend wears hearing aids and asked for her to repeat her answer.  The hostess looked up and said again, very annoyed, a firm "No" and walked away.  We were both kind of shocked.  We walked to the bathroom...there were indeed several open booths that were clean and set ready for guests  in the other area and other groups were seated in that area so it was not an area with no wait staff available. Its NOON on a Friday...were they understaffed??   We were given no explanation or perhaps a "Im very sorry, this is the only table I have, we had a waitress go home and are short staffed."  

It was so uncomfortable to be treated that way thst we decided to leave.  On the way out we told the hostess we were leaving and she just nodded and did not smile or offer any apology or explanation.

I would like to add on a positive note, the waitress that brought water was not at all like the hostess. She was cheerful and kind.
Worst pastrami sandwich I have ever had. Paid $10 for dry meat, cheap bread and a pickle ( which was pretty good.)

Love IT! For a person who doesn't have / doesn't like kids, I go here pretty often. I love the old school ambiance and just the sheer volume of STUFF to look at while dining. The menu is super extensive - I dare you to go and not be able to find anything on the menu to eat.

Con: if you don't like kids, it can be kind of a pain to go while there's a birthday party in progress. But then, you did go to a restaurant with a carousel out front.  :) Have fun!

Ah, I wasn't sure where in the entire state of Wisconsin I could find Matzo ball soup. The answer is here, my friends! The broth is flavorful and the noodles a nice complement. At first I was leery of this place being gimmicky looking, but the turkey and melted cheddar baked potato changed my mind. My eyes were able to wander off and look at all of the moving mobiles on the ceiling and toys galore. In Manhattan terms, think of it as a mix of FAO Schwartz plus Serendipity plus a dash of Times Square showiness thrown in. 

I had to do a double take at our scratched table because at first I thought it was dirty. No, wait! On the inside, it was actually ground up magnets that you could use a pen with attraction to draw. 

I would return for the good food, but be extra prepared with my cheesy tolerance up. Take your friends that can handle the carnival-esque atmosphere :)
It's crazy in a great way!!!  The kids loved it for two hours.  Everywhere they looked they saw something new and interesting to say the least.
If only I had checked the reviews here before wasting 19.00 dollars a 2 pops, a corned beef sandwich and fries. Terrible service, small portions and over priced food. Don't waste your money here.
Good deserts, huge menu (people liked the food too, but I didn't have any). Lots of kitsch on the ceiling, very interesting and unique. Plus a carousel!

Horsey Carousel or mountain high ice cream?  Depending on the day, you can enjoy both!
This place is packed with knick knacks, circus figurines, moving sculptures, toys, you name it all over the walls and ceiling.  If you have ADHD you might want to put on some sunglasses.
There's a carousel outside that you can buy tickets for in the summer, but to be honest there is enough going on inside.  Food is good.  Basic. Hot dogs, burgers, noodles, mac and cheese, salads, etc. 
Ice cream sundaes, cones, and other deserts are delish and just how you remember from your childhood.
Your kids will be wound up on sugar, over stimulation visually and will want a treat at the candy counter on the way out.  Hopefully they'll pass out on the way home and you get some quiet moments in the car.
It's fun.  It's crazy. But those are some good memories.

I just visited Ella's a couple weeks ago after not being in for a few years (as I now live abroad). It definitely has cleaned up its act since I was last in.

The food has always been ok and overpriced, but on this occasion we just got ice cream. GIANT scoops. Yum! (They used to do their own, but these days serve Chocolate Shoppe premium ice cream which is delicious and very high quality). 

The decor is the reason anyone comes back. And it needs a little love, but wasn't as dusty as the last time I visited. 

Ella's - you seemed shinier in the 80s. I hope you will return to your glory. But I still love you all the same.

Holy kitsch!

My fiancée and I went in here recently to see if it lived up to the standards we'd set for the place when we were little kids. The place had begun to fade from my memory so aside from a cacophony of mechanical whirring and children playing I didn't know exactly what to expect.

The décor is just as tacky as I remember. Trains chugging along the walls, flying Bart Simpsons and Yellow Submarines, the creepy little girl on a swing rocking back and forth. The place gets to be a bit of sensory overload, but that's sorta what it's known for. 

The server who took our order was very nice. i have no complaints about the service.

I have both good and bad to say about the food:
+The reuben I got was well built. It didnt get soggy until the very end when it was mostly just kraut and dressing left.
+The flavor of the reuben was great. I wouldn't say it was the best I've ever had, but it can definitely hold its own. The kraut they use is particularly tasty
+I can't believe I'm mentioning this, but the soda. I got a cherry Pepsi, but it's not like cherry Pepsi that you're used to. They use crushed ice and a shot of grenadine to mix it. That in and of itself isn't unusual--you can get grenadine in cola at most any bar or supper club if you ask--but the proportions here are heavenly (and that word isn't an understatement). Usually places add way too much grenadine and it tastes like carbonated cough syrup. I've stopped drinking soda almost entirely except for going out to eat, so to make something relatively mundane like Pepsi taste fantastic is commendable.

-The fries were meh. Nothing stood out about them. They were just bland bits of potato.
-My fiancée got the mushroom and swiss burger, and her patty was burned. She took it apart to show me and it was, indeed, black as a hockey puck on the bottom.

Overall, I'd say that this place is worth stopping into if you have nostalgia about coming here as a kid or if you have children yourself. If you're a transplant to the Madison area and without kids, I'd suggest passing on this place for now. It's not that the food is bad, it's just about average and you don't need to surround yourself with kids and toys to enjoy average food. This place is, ultimately, a novelty and they're very good at being a novelty, but they're not the kind of place I imagine anyone being a regular at.

Now please take my review with a grain of salt, because I never actually had the opportunity to try any of the food at Ella's. I made it inside and had a chance to look around at the wondrous variety of colorful toys and games that would have brought out the kid in me. However, I then looked around and saw dozens of greasy screaming children that made me wretch at the idea that I ever used to be like that. 

The rest of the crowd here didn't do much for the atmosphere as well - morbidly obese hillbillies, old people hooked up to oxygen tanks, waiters with pit stains and spilled food on their clothing...together they created some kind of overwhelming stench that slowly turned my desire to put food into my stomach into an uncontrollable instinct to send it flying straight out.

Once we were seated at a table covered in a thin, sticky veneer that grabbed on to everything it touched, we had had enough. As soon as the waiter left to get our water, we had to sneak out of there. Any longer and I was afraid this place was going to devolve into a scene from a Stephen King movie.

I am torn! My grandma tells me she took me here when I was little. My brother and sisters talk about it as if it's a major part of our childhood. I don't actually have any memories. The ambience/decor is pretty cool with so much to look at and talk about. That's the best part. The ice cream was pretty good...but terribly overpriced! And the hostess who met us at the door had her boobs half hanging out! NOT cool for a children's ice cream shop!
We bought carousel tickets, the ride was long and the kids enjoyed themselves.

I LOVE THEIR HUMMUS.  I would pay lots of money for the recipe. Or buy it in a large tub.  In fact, next time I visit, I just might ask about that latter option... anyway, every time I have ever come I have gotten the hummus platter and I always walk away feeling like I got a great healthy meal.  For a veggie and chickpea plate, it seems a wee bit pricy (I think $8 - I am cheap though), but it's oh so yummy.
All I am going to do here is inform you, if you are in Madison, Wisconsin, you hafta check out Ella's Diner!!!

Used to love this place and came back for the first time in years. Main issue, my sandwich was SMALL. I got a Reuben and it was on small oval bread cut diagonally...the halves were like slightly large hors d'oeuvres. Seriously, regular grocery store bread would have made a substantially bigger sandwich. It was like three bites for each half, ate it in two minutes and it cost $9.50. They did load the rest of the plate with average fries (cost extra). My memory of Ella's from a decade ago is of getting huge sandwiches you couldn't even finish. Yeah, all the toys are cute and fun but the food is a rip off. Service took a long time, didn't check on refilling drinks, etc. Sad to say I probably won't be back.

If you haven't gone to Ella's Deli, treat yourself right and go now! The inside is decorated with endless decor that will remind EVERYONE of their childhoods, which is just the tip of the iceberg. They have a kosher menu with an ice cream shop inside too, and the service is simply unbeatable. Plus, this restaurant is located right on East Wash and is easy to find. :-)
Fun place to eat.  Have becoming here for roughly 25 years.  THe kids loved it when they  were younger, now when travelling in the Madison area, we always try and get there at least once a year.

Cute place. Memorial Day. Our destination restaurant was closed so we back tracked and stopped here. Kids loved it from the beginning. Quirky. Memorable. I had the chicken salad sandwich on rye. The sandwich tasted like one your grandmother would make in her kitchen when you were 7. Nothing wrong with that.   I'm happy our plans changed and we could experience this place. It wasn't fantastic. But for lunch, it was simple and who can be upset about crinkle cut fries.

This is a great way to have a nice lunch/dinner with kids. On the outside is a 1927 carousel in full working condition and beautiful as ever.  You can ride it during the late May to early September timeline (sometimes earlier sometimes later- depends on weather).  Once on you walk into the place, there's tons of things for children to look at. Even some of the tables are interactive. There's even a Rube Goldberg contraption they've put into the ceiling near the deli counter.  I have been here several times and even took friends from out of town here.  The place is a good place for people who have different tastes. We had folks wanting the matzo ball soup, others wanting sandwiches and then others, just something little to snack on. They even have a diverse children's menu.  On top of all of these, they have Chocolate Shoppe Ice Cream (as well as their own custard) and many ice cream creations within their massive dessert menu.  The price wasn't overly expensive and the food is good. Nothing over the top for taste but definitely a must see when in Madison.  Such a unique place.

We only go here when we're so hungry and we have the kids with us (great place to distract your kids so you can eat!) Food is very poor and prices are outrageous crazy high! The service is horrible! Like I said we only go here if we're crazy hungry and have the kids with us!

It's fine for grabbing an ice cream at the ice cream counter. Their ice cream is delicious. I wish the games at the tables would be repaired. And that the tables were less sticky. Customer service could be a little bit better, but I think sometimes they're understaffed. Of course the carousel is awesome.

This is literally the coolest place to have lunch! The decor and table games are so entertaining you have to go back several times to take it all in! The food is actually surprisingly delicious and the there's a large menu to choose from. Some of our family favorites are the potato salad, the cheese curds, the burgers and of course all of the ice cream! Just overall a fun dining experience for everyone!

I ate here years back and I thought it was good, but sadly it's not any more. The decor is cool but the place seemed dirty and the menus were gross to touch. Campground bathrooms are nicer than this place. They had a large menu but nothing good, unless you loved Reuben's and liver and tongues. Food was way over priced. $9 for a tiny sand which and a tiny cup of coleslaw. Food was blah. I would not come back.

Every time I go to Ella's I think, "This is it! This is the time I'm going to get some really great food!" And every time I am wrong.  I am not going to go into detail about the food I've had. I'm a vegetarian, so my menu choices are much slimmer than my meat eating counterparts. However, I've yet to have a meal at Ella's that I would deem "good."  The whole things seems to me kind of like getting a hot lunch meal from school. And let's face it - the food is EXPENSIVE.  Really expensive.  I paid nine dollars for three small blintzes with some sour cream and applesauce that looks like baby food - I get it...it's applesauce, but I guess I was expecting something better than the "old standby." Every time we leave, I'm shocked at how much money we spent.

The good things about Ella's?  The atmosphere. The carousel. The ice cream, which is also insanely overpriced, but for some reason it's ice cream so I'm okay with it.  We had a server the last time who had a smile on her face the entire time and seemed to truly be enjoying her job.  It's a fabulous place to bring people just for the experience, but from now on "the experience" for me is just going to include a dish of ice cream and a ride on the merry-go-round.

I'm giving this 4 stars for the atmosphere and the carousel. I could spend all day in there looking at stuff. I hear the ice cream is really really good but was too full to get any. The fried pickles were very good but....our meals were just...mediocre at best.  I ordered the Chicago dog and the bun was toasted. Toasted?  It should've been steamed.  My dad had the patty melt and said it was just ok.  Very small portions for the price. With this being said though, I would go back. My 2 year old had a ball there and I would to look around some more.

If Willy Wonka had a deli and ice cream parlor, THIS is what it would look like.

You can tell this is a definite tourist stop for kids and those young at heart. It is a true novelty of a place. It's fun and there are animations in every corner of the store.

Its fun that every table has its own theme and entertainment. It's fun that they have a carousel outside and many flavors of ice cream inside. The menu is largely filled with basic items, but nothing stands out as great per say.

Did I enjoy the time here? Yes. Would it be a regular stop? Not really.. but its a great touristy and kid location though.

The staff was generous and genuinely happy to help so I see that as a good reason, if any, to make a come back when I am back in Madison.

This is a good place to take your kid(s) because of all the gizmos and gadgets they have hanging around the restaurant. They keep the kids occupied for a good amount of time.

Service was only okay. Our waitress was friendly and helpful when needed. The downside was that they're so busy when we were there that we only had our water refilled once and it was done when we were almost finished eating. We were only given the kids cups too. I would think that since we have such small cups of water, that they would check often to see if we needed refills but that didn't happen.

The food was not good enough. I wouldn't even say it is okay. I got a burger which came with fries, a pickle and some coleslaw. The pickle and coleslaw was good but I have had better fries and burgers. My burger tasted dry and the fries were plain. My oldest son, who loves fries, tried one and didn't touch them again. He did enjoy the chicken tenders though. The price of the food is okay. I have had better food for the same price at other places.

I have to agree with some people about the cleanliness of this place. While we were waiting for our food, a worker cleaned up one of the booths next to us. He brushed all the leftover crumbs and french fries on to the ground. I thought he would be back to sweep it up but he never returned. The mess was still on the ground when we left an hour later.

You know what?  The food here isn't anything to write home about.

You know what else?   This has never been a destination I would go to for the food anyway.  In fact, if you are coming here just to eat you are missing the point entirely.

What you should be coming here for is the atmosphere, the carousel and the ice cream.  You should be coming here to make memories with your kids (or the kids in your life--nieces for me) and have some ice cream.  I remember this place from my childhood and I defy you to find a child that is not mesmerized with the amount of stuff hanging from the ceiling or tucked inside the many shodowbox-like tables (Ours had a medieval LEGO scene inside it).  

My burger was decent, but I can assure you it wasn't the reason I set foot through the door.

The reason for 2 stars was the atmosphere and the waitstaff and the nice woman hostess. 
We got there around 4 on Thursday. 2 other people in the restaurant. Not busy was a clue. 
I got the Rueben with potatoe salad and a tiny cup of coleslaw. You can get a much better Reuben from Arby's and much cheaper. Same with my friend and grandson. Hamburger and frys mediocre and over priced. Pbj ok frys dry and some overdone. 
We got icecream cones to go and there was crystals in the ice cream   Not good. 
The bathrooms need to be cleaned and remodeled. 
I probably won't be back. Quality down, prices too high. Ella would be sad.

This was fun! A friend we were visiting wanted to take her kids here before they sold, so we met up there. We loved it, especially the Harry Potter chasing the golden snich! The kids loved the carousel. Food was alright. ..kind of pricey and nothing great. But a fun place!

First off, don't go here. Maybe walk in, go 'ahh' then walk out immediately. Don't worry, no one will bother you. There is no hostess waiting to seat you so you'll have plenty of time to sit by the door and look around. Then walk out. Leave. 

A deli? No. Worst meat and bread I've ever had. The menu is confusing, large with no instructions. I order a tukery sandwhich, with mayo. I asked for a hot sandwich. I got a moist bread, with turkey that was microwaved to a Luke warm tempature. 

We couldn't even finish our plate. Figured, why bother. 

The waitress station consists of a pen and a calculator. Nope, there is no system for them to type in your food, check the price. The cooks get the carbon copy of your order, if that. Your bill a
Is the what the calculator typed up and printed. 

Sorry. I'm currently waiting for my bill, so I'm rambling, bored, watching all the servers either sit and talk or get yelled at by other customers who want to leave, or just run around confused.  

Please, don't go here. It's horrible. And probably full of lots of fun germs you can play with at the table. 

New rule, you should only have to pay for what you eat. I would then owe $5 rather than $27.
I'm not a fan of the food there... but I certainly love the black-cherry ice cream they serve! :)

Even though they are closing their doors next week, I still want to write a review because this is my childhood, and a part of me isn't accepting that they will be gone soon. Ella's is like a kid's dream. It's like House on the Rock in restaurant form. I stopped by yesterday to take my 13 month old for the first and last time. He was in awe of all the flying and moving tchotchkes. I was planning on just letting him chew on some of my fries, but saw they had a "baby plate" consisting of peas and carrot bits, vanilla yogurt, apple sauce, mandarin oranges, turkey, and cheese. It was the perfect meal for my little guy! I ordered the matzo ball noodle soup, and it was as good as I remember it. In addition to the soup I had the Wisconsin Cheeseburger, which was an insanely delicious overload of cheesy goodness. My husband had the barbecue burger, and he devoured it in 5 minutes. Accompanied by some crispy crinkle cut fries, it was obvious how impressed he was by how much he licked his fingers. Of course no trip to Ella's Deli is complete without some ice cream, so I had a good old fashioned vanilla shake and my husband, who can definitely stand to gain some weight since defeating cancer, had TWO butter pecan shakes! The waitress did say that this was the time to do it, after all. Waiting in a line outside for almost an hour was 100% worth it! We'll miss you, Ella's!

You don't go to Ella's for the quality of the food, despite the vastness of their menu.

You go to Ella's for the atmosphere - it is every ADD kid's dream! There is so much to look at and interact with, lots of animitronics, and rarely changes in appearance, so you can always look forward to the comfort of seeing all of your old favorites. 

I particularly love that many of the tables are interactive, with glass tops encasing fun games to play with your family and friends.

Plus, they have a big ass carousel, and fun candy and toys for purchase.
