Hands down, the best thing to eat at Ella's is their famous #1 - fried poundcake with vanilla ice cream and hot fudge on top - it is to die for.

Another special item for large groups: their sparkling kazoo (formerly the kitchen sink) - which is 32 scoops of various kinds of ice cream and sherbet in a big metal bowl, covered with every topping imaginable and a huge spoon to dish it out with. - great for parties!

This is a four star review for nostalgia.  I have been coming here since I was a little kid on my way to grandmother's house we go.  If you are taking a youngster (I would say anyone under six) and you walk in looking through their eyes it is pure whimsey.  If you are an adult that can't handle being around a rowdy room of kids' ruckus, not the place for you.  The food is that of a Jewish deli and good.  Recommend the turkey reuben,  Kosher Chicago hot dog and Matzo ball soup.  They love giving free ice cream samples, which is exceptional.  There is so, so much to look at.  Definitely a novelty spot.  If you see a wait all the wait outside the door just keep on driving.  It's pricey but you kind of get a show along with your meal.

This place has really gone downhill.  The prices are absurd, the food is horrible, and some of the decorations that haven't been updated for 30+ years actually scared my kids!!  Last time we went the waitress was more concerned with the table next to us and we actually didn't end up tipping her (we never don't tip, we always tip at least 20%)  That shows how bad the service was!  We won't be going there ever again.
Yup. Insanely expensive. Service is rude and the food is just... not good. For the sad, sad sandwich I got and a bowl of soup? I should have gone to a restaurant downtown. Gross.

Grew up in Madison.  This is a must to visit, and definitely a place to take children: it is fun seeing their fascination with all that this place has to offer.  They also have a merry-go-round that operates in the Summer.  The food's good too: root beer and reuben is hard to beat, let alone the ice cream shop they've got for dessert.

I give this place 5 stars because you don't just go for the food, what Ella's offers is an experience, that that unique experience they do whole hog :)

Decent deli food. Huge menu. Awesome decor FOR KIDS.
Ella's is really a kids place. By now you know they have toys everywhere, that its noisy and it has a carousel. But this place is so much better than any other KIDS PLACE around. I won't name names. It is going to a bit expensive as you will end up buying a toy , a carousel ride, ice cream and lunch for everyone in the group. But at least its not gambling for kids!

Stopped in on a whim for the first time tonight. Looks a bit suspect, but the food, ambiance, and our server, Sara, was top-notch!! We had such a fun time. We weren't sure what to order, as the menu is about 20 pages long(!), but Sara made excellent suggestions and it's great for kids. We will be back!
Cool place for kids lunch. A little pricey and the Ruebens were not what they used to be.

My friends and I stumbled on this lovely place during winter break. If you are a person who has nightmares about moving dolls, this isn't really a nice atmosphere for you. They however do have famous characters on display such as spongebob and Harry potter.

They get most of their flavors from chocolate shoppe ice cream and the rest from other ice cream manufacturers. The food portions are small but the dessert portions are more than enough. Dessert in my opinion can't go wrong but I don't recall anything memorable about the I cream other than the banana split for two.

I am not sure how to rate our experience at Ella's Deli. If I were my five year old, Ella's would get a five star review for sure. But, since I am not five...I need to point out a few things with a more distinguishing eye. 

First things first, my daughter had a great time. She loved the atmosphere, the ice cream and the carousal. We will be back for ice cream and a carousal ride. However I will not eat there again for a variety of reasons: 

-the food is overpriced 
-it wasn't that good 
-the service was not good, the initial host we talked to to get a table for our party of seven was rude, it took a long time to get seated. Another host eventually took care of us, but the initial contact left a bad taste 
-the restaurant was dusty
-the atmosphere was overstimulating 
-the cleaning stations in the middle of the restaurant have got to break some sort of health code
-the baby  changing table is OUTSIDE of the restrooms, so, when a child is being changed you can smell them 
-the menu was large and confusing 

I have a soft spot for places like this. I wish them the best. I hope they are able to renovate and stay Madison's first and best deli!

The atmosphere was quite charming, with multitudes of animatronics and other interesting decor. Waiting for the meal was not at all boring with so much to look at! 
Unfortunately, the food left a little something to be desired. I originally ordered a 'shaved coffee cream' but was told that they were out of shaved coffee. I settled for a frosty mug of root beer, which was charged at the same price as the coffee drink I originally ordered. My dining companion was offered a 'refill' of his cherry Pepsi, but was charged twice for the beverage.
My dining companion also ordered mashed potatoes with his sandwich. Fries were brought and when this was pointed out, a side of mashed potatoes was brought. It looks as though we were also charged for the mashed potatoes.
My pastrami and corned beef Reuben was quite tasty, as was the Cole slaw. I would recommend this sandwich.

Went back for some nostalgia when I brought my family to Madison.  Unfortunately, Ella's has gone downhill fast.  The place is desperate for a relocation and new professional staff.  The guy working the carousel was intimidating people for tips.  Meanwhile, many unruly customers everywhere smoking ciggies and using profanity while kids are trying to enjoy the ride.  Relocate and return to a Madison staple.  This area is horrible.

They cover the walls with tacky crap with blinking lights and annoying little beeping sounds to distract you from the poor quality of the food. 

To call this a "deli" is an insult to all of the real delis out there.

I had a fantastic time at Ella's Deli. I always driven pass this place, and always wanted to come. 

I guess as adults, we have been used to 'generic' kind of dinning after a while. You are being served in a pleasant environment and happy to return. In Ella's Deli, it so unique I was just constantly stunned by all the toys moving around the side and the ceiling on their own. As well as how giant the Sparkled Kazoo. They are all really stimulating. And makes us be reminded, we could just be well stunned by a different kind of experience. And to top that up, the carousel ride was ace. 

Oh and their reuben sandwich and fries were quite tasty too. So they have some decent food too other than these stimulations. The waitresses were all very kind and nice to me. The service was very fast too. I have to say, I'm a little bit sad if Ella's Deli is sold and won't be here anymore. We are going to lose this one of a kind spot in Madison.

i really dont understand how anyone could give anything less than five stars

it has one of those things where a strobe light creates stop-motion
and flying superman's
and ball's rolling through tubes in apparent perpetual motion
and games INSIDE your table

and blintzes, kugel, dr. browns, and FRIED PICKLES

wtf. what is wrong with you people?! is there anything in life you like?!!?

One of my favorite places in Madison. Good coleslaw and I recommend the pump platter salads. Try to save room for some frozen custard.  You have to make it here if you have little kids just for the eclectic collection of toys and "stuff" that creates a great ambiance for kids.

I hate to say it---but this gets my vote for one of the least desirable places to eat in Madison. Their deli food is dry and sandwich portions are meager. Tables improperly cleaned and sticky, food is starchy and canned-tasting, and it's loud and dilapidated. I've been here a few times and besides the awesome merry-go-round in front and some very impressive homemade toys, my experience has repeatedly been very disappointing. Staff are nice though.

It's true, the tables are a little grody, and the service is not spectacular, but there are robotic toys EVERYWHERE. And the ice cream is delicious. And hello, it's JEWISH. They even sell little plush havdalah sets at the front!

I was so delighted with finding this place. We drove in to Madison on our way to Chicago from Minneapolis/St. Paul, and we saw the carousel so we came back after going to downtown. Originally we were only going to grab some ice cream and let our son ride the carousel, but once we walked in and saw all of the fantasticness that was going on and I heard "corned beef," we were staying for dinner.

I have corned beef with pickles and onions, and my husband had the holishkes. Our son had a hot dog and french fries. I though my sandwich was perfect, and the cole slaw was great (wish there had been more!) My husband's food was very good, too, with good portions of his veggies. The bread and muffin that came with his dinner were just incredible. My son liked his dinner as well, but the applesauce was ridiculously small...it was in an over-sized thimble basically.

After dinner we had ice cream. I had Kitty Kitty Bang Bang and Cake Batter Fudge. My son had Superman. My husband had a Blueberry Cheesecake and the one with "everything" in it. The ice cream was incredible, and the girl working the counter (with a large hemp necklace) was just as great.

The prices and food were awesome, and the staff was very good as well. If we're ever back in the area, we'll definitely be back!

First off, the atmosphere is intense. There are old school animatronics everywhere. The tables are shadow boxes filled with knicknacks and toys of antiquity. It seems quaint by today's digital standards but that's part of the charm. 

It's somewhere everyone who spends any time in, or driving by (it's 3 minutes off the I, depending on stop lights and along the main drag of East Washington). 

The food is Kosher Deli standard, for the most part. The menu style is the same as ever, which can be a bit hard to read as formatted/organized. Whether you want kugel, a pastrami on rye or whatever, the quality is solid. 

If you have kids, it's even better with the carousel outside, but by no means necessary. All those little motors running means it's not the quietest location, so if you're looking for intimate conversation, this is not the place. Otherwise, give it a whirl.
Dry pastrami on dry bread and overpriced ice cream. The food here is a star less than a  chain diner. Fun for the kids but not worth the money.

I used to come here all the time when I was a kid with my grandpa and grandma when we visited Madison. So, it has sentimental value and memories. It is extremely unique place, I have never been in a restaurant such as this one. I could literally spend hours looking around at all the fun decorations. Hours. Food is average, ice cream is fun, but the environment and memories are the reason why I would still come back.  

Do not change Ella's Deli. Ever. I promise I will come when I have kids of my own.

This is a fun touristy destination place to go in Madison. The kids were happy,  the grownups were happy, because merry-go-rounds and ice cream are happy things.
They had a baby plate with little things to try for my friend's  little one, which was a nice touch. I had an egg salad sandwich and matzo ball soup, which was OK. I don't like celery, but it's not their fault. Pretty cheap lunch, considering... Wierd thing is that they don't provide crayons and paper for the kids to draw on-which would have been nice. we had a good time with old friends.

Ya know, I didn't have high hopes upon entering this magical circus land cafe.

But - they sure did surprise me.

The soup - you must get the soup.  Homemade - and delicious.  

The reviews are all over the map for this here deli - and I gotta say that my experience was really quite pleasant.  Our server (I wish I remembered her name) was top notch.  She was so sweet and friendly and really made for a great dining experience.

I loved going here when I used to live in Madison. Overall, the food is okay, nothing special about it. But, this place seems whimsical to little kids. It's fun to watch them oohs and aahs over neat animatronics. They used to have small carousel set up outside. So, not really a place for foodies, but worth the visit for the little ones.

the review is definitely leaning towards the unique nature of the inside rather than the food, and i can't quite say that i've been to a place like this before.  well, we used to have the submarine thing in California.  

the food is so-so and not priced to match its flavoring.  even when it looks good as they bring it out, it is average deli food.  i concur that the menu is extensive and its really difficult to figure out what want to go for that day.   even soda costs more.  when we were there, there wasn't a whole lot of kids (it was a Sunday late morning), and we got to enjoy playing around with our table (it was the one with iron fillings covering some images, so you can play with it with magnets to form beards over ladies and such).  its a place worth coming to once, but not sure if it is worth a second visit if you're here for the food.  

nonetheless, unique.

This place is definitely for kids. Used to come here all the time when I was a little enjoying all the things on the walls, inside the tables and ceiling and the carousel. 

Now lately just for a quick stop in for ice cream. Which they no longer make besides the vanilla and chocolate used in their sundaes. Now they use Chocolate Shoppe.

Recently stop in for dinner for old time sake. They have extensive menus for both regular and dessert. So takes a long time to read it but it is available online to look over too.

I started off with a kugel. A sweet noodle cheese dish with farmers cheese, sour cream and egg noodles with a side of sour cream and mashed strawberries. Can almost be compared to a cheesecake minus the crust. Now it was mighty tasty and would highly recommend it if you have never had a kugel. But it tasted just like the one I make at home. So I can easily have it at home. Plus I like to add raisins and a nut topping for texture.

For my entree I got Holishkes. sweet & sour stuffed cabbage rolls filled with beef & rice topped with tomato sweet & sour sauce. Comes with a cinnamon muffin, sweetbread a bowl of soup and a choice of two additional side. I got fries and mixed vegetables. For 12.99 I thought it was a good value for the quanity and I left stuffed put that being said. The filling to the cabbage was bland but the tomato sauce helped out there. The muffin was dry. Sweetbread was ok. I got the Sweet & Sour Cabbage soup which was different and could of had a bowl of it. The fries were the frozen kind and the mixed vegetable were peas and carrots. Not a big fan of peas but thats my fault of not asking what kind of veggies.

The service was friendly and laid back put not too badly. But there was only a couple of tables full on a late thursday night. So not sure how it would be busy.

Had no room to try one of their Grilled Pound Cake Sundae my dad loves. A return  visit in the future maybe.

Ok for taking the kids for some ice-cream and to kill some time.

The food is overpriced and not much care is taken for the quality of food they serve.  It's what you would expect from a concession stand or worse.

The servers were fine, but i would not return for any of their menu other than dessert

I have never had a satisfying meal at Ella's.  They have a few great things, but they are all over-priced, and kinda not worth it.  I mean, the croutons on the salad are delicious, but it's not worth paying $10 for a salad that tastes like the salad bar at Copp's grocery store to get them.  The fried pickles are good, but why would you just order a meal of fried pickles?  The ice cream is okay, but there is better ice cream in Madison.

The atmosphere is cool, but there are always screaming kids to deal with.  Overall, Ella's isn't worth the hype.

I can see how this place used to be a fun spot for children because our 3 year old enjoyed the crazy environment and carousel.  However, it's crossed the line into run down and a little creepy.

The food was horrendous.  The worst we've had since moving to Madison 8 months ago.  And it was very expensive for the quality.  I'm glad we came, saw, and will not be back.

Hmmm... where to begin... OK. If you live in Madison, you have to go to Ella's at least once. I figured I'd check it out, because, it's, like, a Kosher deli and those are hard to find in Wisconsin and I definitely have frequent cravings for good old east coast-style Jewish deli stuff. BUT, I made the huge mistake of not being stoned out of my skull when I went... this place is a trip! What the f*ck is up with the decor? Definitely clutter city in here with all sorts of crazy robotic puppet contraptions and automated devices, toy trains, etc - probably charming in the daytime, pretty weeiirddd late at night. The food was ok - not bad, but a little overpriced considering it wasn't exactly the greatest deli I've ever had, to say the least. It's a cool old place though; definitely has character. I just think the food could be a little better, and the place a bit cleaner. But, if you're, like, f*ckkkin BAKED, MANNN, you probably won't care about those things. Definitely worth checking out for the experience.
I don't have kids, but have been here when others want to entertain. Take out the knick backs, merry go round, and you have an average deli.

This is our granddaughter's favorite restaurant.  There was no other place to celebrate her sixth birthday.
The food is not fancy--but it reminds me of the Jewish delis we visited when I was a kid.
My husband and I shared a "platter" with pastrami and corned beef, Swiss cheese, Russian 
dressing and slaw.  Though meant for one person, it was a lot of food for two!
Another person in our party had lox with cream cheese and bagel and she loved it.
And the ice cream was perfect!

This place was incredibly disappointing. The servers were apathetic, the place was dirty, and the food was average at best. 

This place had a lot of promise, and maybe was a fun place to be in its better days, but my family couldn't get out of there fast enough.

They were out of French fries, and it was only 6pm on a Monday night. The server came outside to hunt us down on the carousel (which was about the only thing my 7 year old and 4 year old seemed to enjoy) to inform us that there were no fries.

We spent nearly $50 on dinner and another $10 on the carousel, and left there feeling like we may have enjoyed fast food more than what we had just experienced. A waste of a meal out!

If you are reading Yelp, then chances are, this place isn't for you.  I'll just lay out my experience:

-temperature was cold
-the "binder" menu felt dirty
-very overpriced
-napkins on the floor
-Reuben sizzler was dry, corned beef was dry, bread was dry
-very overpriced for portions and quality
-sundaes seemed small (I didn't get one)

Now that I think about it, just go to Culver's.

If you go expecting a typical deli experience, forget it. Go for the atmosphere!

We KNEW it was going to be a circus (literally) but even then were impressed/overwhelmed by the place- wild!!

The menu was a surprise- a binder seemingly done by a kid who just discovered Print Shop. 2 pages of banana splits alone, in the $6.75-7.50 range, but then a rather slim drink list. I really felt this could have been done better and still kept the fun feel.

I got a classic Reuben, my wife a Mediterranean Salad, and we shared a delicious Zanzibar dark chocolate banana split. The meal was perfectly good, but the split was delicious! The Reuben was $8.80+2.75 for the combo platter (fries). The fries were perfectly crispy, the side of slaw was nice, and the Reuben could have been a bit thicker for the price but was tasty.

The service was warm and friendly. I suspect the decor drives the staff slightly crazy over time, but it is in a good way. There was a bit of a line at the small check out stand/gift shop but not bad. 

The decor is... is... look, you just got to see it. The various You Tube videos don't do it justice. The small gift shop is equally fun and kitschy.

We'll go back, especially if we can drag along some kids!

Five stars for the atmosphere, three for the food, four for the desserts and service.

The decor is absolutely amazing.  An overload of spinning everythings, carnival games, Rube Goldberg like machines, everything a kid could possibly by fascinated by.  I also greatly appreciate that not much has changed since my childhood.  They could stand with a little more maintenance (some of the lights are out, some of the spinning things are duct taped) but I'd much rather have that than a full on remodel that loses all of the charm.

The food isnt bad, but it is disappointing, especially for the prices.  Based on what we tried in our most recent visit . . . the fried pickles were great.  My chicken noodle Matzo soup tasted like canned soup with a large stale cracker in it.  My reuben was good but nothing I couldnt get elsewhere.  Other diners in our party enjoyed their food, which included a salad, a hummus plate, a hot dog, chicken tenders, and fries.  The desserts were good-- I mean, how can you have a bad sundae using Chocolate Shoppe Ice Cream.

For the record, one of the other reviewers complained about bugs and cleanliness.  I've never seen those issues in decades of going.

Yes, the menus are weird.

I have chosen this place many times for various occasions both as a child and as an adult. Fantasy land was always what kept me coming back and reminiscing of childhood. However a few months ago I had a Jewish co-worker.  We got to talking about eating out. I inquired if his family frequented Ella's (They advertise kosher right on the outside of the building). These were his words, "They aren't actually Kosher. My family and I were so excited, we went, we sat down, we started asking some questions, and left."

I was shocked. This restaurant has many other attractions then it being "kosher".  If they aren't kosher, they shouldn't advertise it that way. I'll never eat there again.

Absolutely most crazy place I've been to my entire life, and by far my favorite! Every corner you look at, every inch of every surface, is covered with fun stuff. And it's current! They even have harry potter on a broomstick! An experience like no other. Oh, and get a milkshake!! And good luck choosing which one.

Something different but cool !! The place is great for all ages. The decor is pretty nice, every where you look, you will find something different that will catch your attention. They also have a carousel out side if the kids want to get on it.  We only went to this place for the ice cream because the food doesn't look that great. The ice cream was very good!! The service was excellent too.

One of the most kid-friendly restaurants ever, and know that most of the clientele are going to be of the under-12 crowd. I grew up going to Ella's Deli, and this year I was able to take my 2-year old. She loved it! The matzo ball soup with noodles keeps bringing us back, and you can get pretty much any kind of deli sandwich you can think of at this establishment, and they are all pretty good. The price has certainly crept up over the years, and the cost doesn't match the food quality, which is frustrating. But let's be real - you don't go there for the food quality. You go there for the ambiance -- the 1920s carousel and the explosion of decoration inside.
Oh, and for those complaining about too many loud kids? Look around. Clowns on the wall? Check. Robot greeting you at the door? Yup. Candy counter? Sure thing. Use these context clues, turn around, and find a McDonalds.
This restaurant is now CLOSED.  Their last day was Jan 21.   It was a fun place for kids with some amazing contraptions all over the restaurant and a carousel out front.

Granted it was 90 degrees outside, but it was about 80 inside the restaurant. Air conditioner was not keeping up and it made for a miserable meal. 

The food was mediocre and the waitstaff was slow, uninspired and unfriendly. 

This used to be a neat place to take kids. Don't bother. Find a nicer place- like the Mc Donald's down the street.

Food was average. Ambiance is great for kids. Lots of doodads and trinkets and thingamabobs. Prices were good, especially the lunch specials. $5 meatloaf with mashed potatoes for example. Waiter got soup and salad dressing wrong. It took about 1 hour to get food once seated (an eternity for 3 year olds). It was crowded. There was a wait to get in. They actually ran out of glasses. Matzo ball soup was "terrible". The broth tasted like dirty water. Waiter didn't ever check in.

This place was like magic to me as a kid. I used to beg my parents to go here, but now that I'm an adult, I can see why they were reluctant. The food isn't great, and the service is pretty average. That, and the combination of animatronics, knick-knacks, and screaming children is enough to make anyone want to make sure they have some aspirin with their meal.

All in all, it's fun for the kids, but make sure you take it in moderate doses.

When we first visited Madison in 1995 we stopped here with our then 9 year old daughter. It was a good time.  The decor was charming and the ice cream we'd remembered was rich,  creamy and generous. So 20 years later and as a lark,  my wife and I dropped in again. To cut to the chase, I ordered a hot fudge sundae and my wife a strawberry soda. The ice cream was flavorless , granular with ice crystals and certainly less than generous, not that that was a bad thing. I had a ribbon of fudge around the periphery of the glass, a puff of cream and done. No nuts, no cherry but $6.50. I wondered why the menu said extra hot fudge,  .95 cents.  Now I know. I asked my wife about hers. Same flavorless ice cream,  no real strawberries but what to me  tasted like strawberry ester. So basically icy granular ice cream , a shot of pink chemical and some soda water. When asked by our waitress how we liked it I described it as flavorless. "I'll inform the manager" was her response. Judging from the myriad complaints about the food going back awhile here on Yelp,  it seems the complaints are falling on deaf ears.  I thought being robbed with a pistol wielding person is the more likely scenario in life than one using a soda glass. Go at your own risk. It's your money. It's Kopp's or Leon's for us.

I wouldn't say I'm a huge fan of this place because the food menu was kind of limited in what I would want to eat, but the food that I did end up choosing was very good. Everyone was nice and friendly there and of course it was a fun atmosphere to be in. The tables even have environments inside of them that are interactive, but unfortunately ours didn't work.

I agree with everyone on the food quality.  Terribly overpriced and subpar at best.  The "Midwest famous" Reuben was very small, standard taste and unimpressive, and $9.95 with only a pickle and small cup of coleslaw. Add another $3.25 for crinkle cut fries or another type of potato side.  That is considered the "combo"(no drink with that combo though).  

The fried pickles were good as was the coleslaw.  For the price though I expect a lot more.  I was surprised at the amount of business they were doing for that quality at those prices.  

The carnival atmosphere and old time deco with  kitschy props was almost worth another star until we went out to take a ride on the carousel and one of the rudest people I have ever met was running it. He was practically yelling at the kids "now what are we not supposed to do?" Before they even entered.  And then he answered every time (because no one knew what he wanted), "we aren't supposed to run so we can all have fun"!  He was seriously barking it at kids who hadn't even had the chance to ride yet.  My daughter took a step back behind me and hid. He would make a better surly bartender than someone who greets the kids.  Interesting and fun inside atmosphere though and if you just go for the desserts you are likely to enjoy it more.

As an admitted crusty old fart, one would think that I would stay miles away from Ella's. Quite the contrary my friends. I would not consider a trip to Madison complete without a visit. 

I agree with many that the food is nothing special, but I have never really had a "bad" meal here either. I tend to stick to soup and variations on a corned beef / pastrami theme and I do ok. Tonight after spending the day at the anti- Walker / pro union rally downtown, we added a special treat to our usual order. We split the caramel apple crisp (ala mode no less). It was deeeeeeeeelicious!!!!

Anyhow, I come to Ella's time and again because I love the atmosphere. It is as though Rube Goldberg went crazy in a toy factory.  Even in my dotage, I can see this place through the eyes of a child. It helps to keep me young at heart. Yes, it is a bit over the top, but it ranks high on my Kitchy Kool list!!
SLOW service. Waited 45 minutes after ordering a simple lunch.  Excellent food but you will be VERY hungry when it arrives and water refills were not offered.

Came for dessert for our out of town guest. Ordered pound cake without ice cream. Menu says pound cake great by its self and? even better with ice cream. I can't eat dairy. This man comes over. Doesn't introduce himself and says he is going to have to start inforcing no pound cake without ice cream. Had no idea it was an issue. Why tell me. Wait staff should be informed. Cake was awful anyway. Not coming here anymore.

I haven't been to Ella's in a long time and I was pleasantly surprised on this visit.  They really work hard to maintain all the...I don't even know what to call it...stuff.  Everything in there is moving and dancing and rolling and spinning and it's just a lively atmosphere topped off by a ride on a carousel.  So cool.  Our server was great too.  This would be a 5-star review if their prices were more reasonable for what you get.  I'd be fine with the cost of the reuben if it only had more meat - good fries, good coleslaw, my daughter's hot dog was on a nice bun, but the dog was tiny.  Oh well.  We'll be back for sure.

If being surrounded in a loud, model carnival/circus ambiance is your thing, you might ... ugh, who am I kidding?   The food is crap.  The ice cream is mediocre.  Every surface you touch is sticky.  

You'd think that a "deli" that promises the "Midwest's best reuben sandwich, for over 55 years" would at least live up to a level of mediocrity, but two bites into a sauerkraut sandwich on sourdough, lightly seasoned with a slice of corned beef, left me physically upset that anyone would serve that to a paying customer.  And then you see the price ... $9.10 for a slice of corned beef on bread?  Really?

1 star deserves at least something nice said ... we had a lot of ... napkins ... I guess.  They stuck to the sticky surfaces.

Every time I come to Madison, I always come to Ella's Deli. Only for the dessert....

I've never had their food. 

The Old Fashioned Banana Split was delicious, especially the pineapple topping. Yum. 

Have fun exploring all of the cool ceiling pieces and neat pieces around the sides.

I was here once. I was so terrified of all the crap and toys and dead doll eyes everywhere that I bolted with my date before ordering with an apology to the waitress. Yeek! This place is like Coraline or something! If your kid is scared of clowns, do NOT go here! Also, the tables are dirty.

Ella's Deli is too close to my house not to go there. I don't see myself ever being a regular, but it's a fantastic place for kids. it keeps them busy and even gets them to eat a little. Ella's needs some major improvements in their food selection. we have bought their ice-cream multiple times and wereways happy with it. When I  finally took my niece there to look at all the amazing decor they have, we decided to give their food a try and it was not impressive at all. we tried their hot dogs and fries, a Ruben and coleslaw and a soup. all of which were bland and happily forgettable. We still left the place with a smile as my niece loved everything she saw there, and ate some of her food even though she didn't like it just to stay there a bit longer.

Visiting from out of town.  Thought it might be fun and entertaining for our kids.  I will give it a thumbs up for being very stimulating, over the top, and a bit eccentric....most of our kids got a kick out of the multiple "moving" decorations.  On the other hand, the food itself was far from delicious.  Chicken strips were the best option at our table. The burger I ate was charred on the outside and pink on the inside....the bun was rock hard.  My husband had a Chicken sandwich....they must use a frozen chicken patty....not much taste and his bun was just as hard! French Fries were not worth $3.25 upgrade.  
Ice cream was decent....
Would I go again?  One time visit was enough for me.

The food here is terrible. Even the Ice cream is bad. But this has one of the most unique and memorable interiors I've ever seen. And my son loved our light up aquarium table and our seat looking at the carousel. 

One time visit, but nothing special.

Ella's Deli: what dreams and/or nightmares are made of, depending on what you're into. This was my fourth visit to Ella's; it was a place I drove past many times as a kid, but never a place we stopped. I've only experienced it as an adult, and it's a trip.

Highlight: the carousel out front. We rode it once and it was pretty fun. 

Inside, there are toys, puppets, games, and more hanging from and attached to every available surface. You will be overstimulated no matter what age you are. You may be delighted by it all, or terrified. There are a few too many clowns for my taste, but overall I'm more amused than anything. 

Half of my trips have been with small children, and that enhances the experience because they're the ones the entire establishment is aimed at. 

I do love that they have some old-school soda counter favorites like egg creams and phosphates - I loved the phosphate I had years ago on a visit, but this last time the ratios were bit off. 

Food and prices are where Ella's falls most flat, though. Everything on the menu is crazy expensive (a plate of franks & beans is $14.30; a baked potato with broccoli cheese sauce is $10.99; a bagel & lox is $10.15; two-scoop ice cream sundaes are about $8). If the quality was super high I'd understand, but everything I've had has been pretty terrible. Turkey sandwich - bland and not piled high like you would expect of a true deli sandwich. Veggie burger - out of a box, burnt, and served plain on a bun. On this most recent trip I kept it simple and ordered cheese fries for almost $5 - crinkle-cut fries out of a bag covered in processed cheese sauce from a can. This is exactly what I expected for cheese fries, but for the price it's nothing special. 

I do still want to get a group of people together to order the Sparkled Kazoo sundae for the sheer spectacle, and I'll happily tag along with friends who have kids because it's fun watching them try to take it all in. I think in the future, though, I'll skip the food.

OK so really cool place for kids to see with tons of things hanging from the ceiling moving all over with a circus type atmosphere. And this is a kosher Jewish style deli so no bacon or pork chops which is fine with me. However the place is a little dirty overall. Not sure I'd let my kids paw all over the various novelty things in the dining area as many looked awfully tired and dirty. Bathrooms not very clean either. The food was expensive and not as impressive as I had hoped. We split an order of friend pickles which were the best thing we had although they were barely warm when they hit the table. The chicken noodle motza soup was average but again, was barely warm. I had a the pastrami on rye and the meat was ok, a little dry and not very warm and the rye was a little dried out. Sandwich not very big either. After being to some of the NYC delis over the years, I expected a piled high pastrami but it was fairly small. Fries also room temperature warm. A mushroom swiss burger was ordered but seemed mediocre at best and was not finished. Lunch for two was $45 before tip which seemed like a lot of cash for an average lunch. But come on, a bowl of soup $5.20? Soft drinks $2.45 with no refills? A small pastrami sandwich $10 and another $3.25 to add a little pile of crinkle cut fries from your food service distributor? I know this place is a historical icon and a great place to bring little kids but they could at least step up the quality of the food for the prices and maybe close for a day and take some soap and water to the place.

The atmosphere makes this place. It's pure nostalgia and it still reminds me of being a kid. The food is so so. Go with a sandwich. Soup is great. Ice cream is almost a must here. At least check it out if you have kids

The ice cream is delicious and the atmosphere is one of a kind. It's not amazing food but you don't really go there just to get a stellar meal. I loved this place as a kid and I love it as an adult too. My girlfriends and I have a tradition that anytime one of us has a breakup we go here and split a big ice cream treat. It always makes things better :)

A whimsical collection of childhood fun. Ella's takes you back to a time unknown with antique toys- all in operation. You can't miss the carousel up front, it screams for attention. 

Once you get inside, it's a rollercoaster of emotions. Overwhelming, almost. There's toys on toys on toys. Above, below, side to side, you can't look anywhere without a monkey popping out of a hat or an elephant rearing its trunk. 

We came for an ice cream date with friends. I really appreciate the "mini" scoop they offer in a sugar, cake or bowl for $1.99. The Ella's Birthday Cake is incredible! Quite possibly my favorite ice cream ever, which says a lot considering the great ice cream options that my hometown in Ohio has to offer. 

There's about 25 ice cream options including super man, a rocky road twist and traditional vanillas. I did not get a peek of the menu but while I was scoping it out online, it looked extremely expensive :(

At the check out counter, you'll be pleased to find candy sticks and candy buttons (!!!). You can purchase tokens for the carousel up front and let your little ones enjoy a ride on a Badger mare or Green Bay steed. Overall, excellent place to stop for ice cream on your way through Madison.
Great place for kids.  Sandwich list is HUGE!   Look for Harry playing Quidditch.

If you don't have attention issues, this place is awesome. The food is mediocre, but the toys and collections are extremely entertaining to view throughout the meal. However, if you get easily overwhelmed by noisy places, lots of visual noise, and just general chaos around, I wouldn't recommend Ella's.

Well, my grandkids are in town so I was forced to bring them here. The only time that I ever eat here is when they come to town. One thing is for sure, if not for all the attractions for the kids, this place would never be able to exist.

Starting with the slow footed host with the red clown hair to the assortment of servers who all seem to be rejects from the Ringling Bros side shows, this place is simply horrid.

The wait staff are slovenly and the food quality and presentation is just plain awful. I had a feta and tomato omelet (didn't think even they could screw that up) the chef or cook or whatever they call them at this hell hole neglected to strain the "fresh" tomatoes, so the omelet was soaking wet on the inside with 2 large clumps of feta cheese.

My advice is to avoid eating here at all costs, I've lived here 15 years and Ella's has consistently delivered the worse food in town. Kids love seeing all the stuff on the walls and ceilings and of course the merry go round but having to eat a meal here really is cruel and inhuman punishment.

My boyfriend and I decided to check Ella's out one night for dinner.

The place was packed with screaming children (which I suppose isn't surprising, considering the carousel and decor - but still, not my bag). Our table was sticky, our silverware wasn't clean, and the food was mediocre. I almost lost my appetite when I looked up at all of the creepy, dusty toys hanging from the ceiling. The only saving grace was the ice cream - but in Madison, you can get good ice cream just about anywhere.

I know this place is a Madison institution, and I really wanted to like it, but mostly it just grossed me out. I might order food or ice cream to go, but I will not dine in the restaurant ever again.

Great if you're under 5yrs old and care only about the cartoon themed decor and merry go round. My children love this place. I enjoy seeing how amused they are...which is the only reason I give this place 3 stars.

The food deserves 1-2 STARS. There needs to be more attention to the food here. The food is meh...not enjoyable or tasty at all.

I will most likely not dine here again. However I will drop by with the kiddos for dessert and a few rides on the merry go round.

I wasn't going to write a review, but now I feel compelled. Stop in for lunch after children's museum. Had to ask to be seated after being ignored. Food was ok (chicken matzo had mictoparticles of chicken/carrot and mutes flavor...Ruben was good). There was a server and a buser talking in the corner booth. The buser was swearing every third word. He could see me and my family with a 3 and 5 year old, but still carried on. Will not be returning.
Cute, worth taking the kids to, food is solidly okay. You go to Ella's more for the experience than the cuisine.

Yes the prices are high because you are paying for the experience as much as the food.  (There's a restored carousel included with your meal!!!). This place is jam packed with entertainment. Most a kids fantasy and mine is almost 17 years old.  She made us stop when she saw it from the road.  ( we were passing through to breakfast somewhere downtown)
I think you have to know what to order.  The French toast plates were AMAZING!  Huge fluffy pieces of challah bread lightly dipped and grilled.  And it's enough for two, possibly three people so share.  The 3  of us should've only ordered two eye also had a side of corned beef, offered instead of bacon, with that.
I had Ella's plate:  scrambled altogether:  eggs, lox and onions with bagel.  Delicious.   Stick to the breakfast menu.
Waitress was great:  covering a party of 5 adults plus 6 children  next to us but was right there to refill drinks throughout.
This is such a fun place.   Keep looking around and you'll see something new.  Every table is some sort of game or toy.  It's amazing all the antiques here.

The only reason this isn't five stars?  Omg, the hostess.  We almost walked out before she seated us.  She looks like she would rather die than be there.  Equally as miserable ringing up our $50 tab.  Leaves you sad and this isn't a sad place.  Too bad.

If you like sensory overload from Rube Goldberg contraptions this is your place. Don't let the word "deli" fool you. The food is so so but get a sundae or milk shake. I read reviews that its not as good as it used to be, it never was you just grew up.

Loved it! Had borscht and nova lox and it was delicious. I am from out of state, I wish my daughter was here she would love it! Staff was friendly and service great. I will be back any time I come to Madison

If you like kitsch and ice cream this is the place for you! Great selection of deli favorites from matzoh ball soup to Reubens to blitzes and more. The kids will lose their minds with all the stuff going on here.

We were meeting a couple people quickly in Madison, and not knowing the place at all - decided to meet up at the "giant carousel place". We pulled in and were pleasantly surprised by the large dedicated parking lot. 

Inside the situation gets insane. Right when you walk in you are at risk of poking an eye out with the millions of flying things. There are unicyclists, clowns - even a harry potter on a broomstick that are hanging from wires all over the place. 

There were tons of tables that had kitschy little trinkets under the glass - some even moved and were interactive! The server station is in the middle of the restaurant. The menu looks like a different middle schooler designed each page. The deli, which is what they started as, is down to about 10 logs of meat. The ice cream selection was good, and we both settled only for a cone and not a meal. The 'gift shop' area was a cramped little cash register with some old candy, creepy stuffed animals and little knick knacks. 

While we didn't eat, the reviews of the food seem fine enough. The carousel is cute and a nice little addition. Not sure I'd ever venture specifically to come here, but it was a cute little meeting spot.

I've never been here before now and I wish as a little kid, I would have had to opportunity to come to a place like this! It was such a good experience. 
It was a little weird to be an adult without a child there but they still treated us the same. Our waiter was a little awkward but the food was fantastic and the ice cream was perfect at the end of our meal. 
Unfortunately, I don't plan on staying in the Midwest long enough for me to have children here but if I did, this would be a regular thing for my family!

This place is still in business for the ambience, not the food.  But that's ok.  I still think everyone should go at least once.  If you're just there for the ice cream, then that's perfect, as its chocolate shoppe ice cream, and the dessert menu is 3x as big as the food menu. :D
As long as you look at the ceiling, you're in a world of fantasy. Unfortunately you sometimes have to look at your plate, where things are not as fantastic.

The food is okay but not great, but you have to experience this place at least once, especially if you have kids.  There's a carousel outside and inside there are so many things for the kids to look at from Dumbo flying across the restaurant to singing feet! Last time we were seated near the front door and I loved watching the kids walk in and just stare at the ceiling. We've only had sandwiches and they are okay..nothing real special. Ice cream is good and you get a lot for the money. An interesting and different place. Try it at least once for the experience.

I am not longer a youngin but oh boy do I remember the fun I had here. Decorations more like deteriorations! The ice cream is good but where can you find bad ice cream in Wisconsin.

The red haired host dude is creepy and enjoys staring at customers. I was  too generous in what I said, he LEERS.

Gross.

Have been coming here for years food is good not spectacular or anything but hubby likes the pastrami old school crinkle fries reminds me rennies the food is overpriced imo chilli was awful kids meals ok don't get the hot dogs unless your kids are use to kosher dogs ice cream is very good recommend the grilled pound cake sundaes many times we come just for ice cream service is generally solid a few bad times but probably been here 60 times the atmosphere is 5 stars for families games built into the tables a menagerie of things in the air plus the carousel out front I'd give it 4 stars but I always feel I should get more for buck

If this place had better food, I might come visit Madison more often just for the fabulously weird animatronic awesomeness that is Ella's decor. The tables are interactive games! There's Harry Potter and Sponge Bob flying around the ceiling! There's a giant robot and a giant banana!  I could go on and on.  If there's even a fragment of an inner child hidden inside of your ragged adult exterior, you HAVE to come see this.

All of this awesomeness is the only reason why I'm giving this place three stars, because the food they served us was abysmal.  As a Jew, I'm kind of horrified that this place has the word "deli" in it.  We shared the holischkes, which is a much-beloved stuffed cabbage dish prepared by Jewish grandmothers everywhere.  Ella's "holischkes" consisted of undercooked cabbage and stringy beef. Worst of all, instead of simmering the cabbage rolls for hours in sweet-and-sour sauce, these imposters had spaghetti sauce blopped on top!  This was served with boxed mashed potatoes and bad canned gravy, along with limp, defrosted frozen peas and carrots.  If someone tried to serve this on the East Coast, the cook would have a line full of angry Jewish grandmothers giving him a piece of their minds.

My daughter's bagel and lox tasted okay.  But the bagel was clearly from a package -- not deli worthy!  The ice cream was okay -- my husband had a good malt, but the so-called famous pound cake sundae was mediocre and very overpriced.  The grilled pound cake just tasted stale.

Would I go again? Well, probably.  Like other Yelpers have said, going for ice cream and skipping the food is probably the way to go.

Gave this place a visit again as we were in Madison. It has become one of our family's fav restaurant to go to everytime when we are in Madison not for food but to check on all the toys they have in there.
All the creations are amazing and look like made with love. Owner Ken shared his story of his love for Carousels and how he has spent hours creating each and every one of them over the past 40 yrs.
Food Menu is very very elaborate and has good portion size.
A must visit with kids for all the fun and action in there!

I've been here multiple times since moving to Madison a few months ago.  My son and the kids of friends who I have brought here love all of the gizmos flying around and the interactive tables.

For a cheery place like this, the wait staff isn't as chipper as you would think.  Additionally, it takes FOREVER to get your food.  Okay, not forever, but I mean, c'mon, it shouldn't take 30 minutes to get a kid's hot dog and fries.  One time I waited nearly an hour at the restaurant to pick up an order of 3 regular combos and a kid's combo.

As for the food, it's okay.  I usually get a sandwich, either a reuben or a grilled cheese, and whatever I get is usually good but isn't worth the price. What's weird is that the two times that we ordered take out, each time my sandwich tasted better than when I've eaten it at the restaurant.

However, I would go back because the kids love it and though it is expensive, sometimes it's easier for someone to make me a reuben than to make one at home.  Plus, one of these days I'd like to try the pound cake sundae.  That sounds good.

If you  have young or young at heart children you need to bring them here at least once..the decor can keep someone with add sitting still...wait staff is pretty friendly..food by and large was just ok and a little pricey for what you got, that being said the menu is very expansive and i cant imagine someone going there and not being able to find something they want to try..there is a carousel out front for kids to ride which is another plus for the kids.

The only thing that has changed at Ella's in 20 years is the cover of their menu.  It's refreshing to know that papier mache rots slower than my mind does.  With tables, walls and ceilings buzzing with mechanical toys and games, and a full-fledged carousel operating during the summer, the environment proves to be kid-friendly, although as a kid I recall my taste buds not being well adapted to the bitter Kosher-style deli flavors I now eat with zeal: sweet and sour cabbage soup, open-faced reubens piled high with sauerkraut and swiss cheese (all this along with a side of cole slaw, and perhaps my zealousness is truly just geared towards cabbage), noodle kugel, cheese blintzes.  My "mature" taste buds still cringe at the sight of tongue sandwiches and gefiltefish, but I can look past this.  Treat yourself to a salad --- their croutons are fried in magical high-penetrating butter.  Their ice cream comes courtesy of Madison's local Chocolate Shoppe, and is made ever the more extravagant when served over pound cake and topped with hot fudge.
Great for kids, a lot of fun. The ongoing attractions keep kids entertained all night. The carousel is great when its open. Decent food.

Expensive!!!!
That is the only word I have for Ella's.  We ate here on a Saturday for lunch.  It had great ambiance and the kids loved it.  There were 4 of us.  We all had sandwiches and my cousin and I shared a $12 sandwich plate with all the fixins.  My wife and his girlfriend had sandwiches and we ordered 3 drinks and a water.  The kids ate off of our plates as they always do.  I figured the bill was going to be around $40 because we didn't even order ice cream.  3 drinks, 2 sandwiches and 1 "shared sandwich" and our bill was $61.62.  WTH?!?!?!?

I went over it with a fine-tooth comb and noticed they charge almost $5 for a small order of cheese fries.  The drinks were $3 each and their sandwiches were over $10 each.  WTH?!?!?!?!?

I couldn't believe how much they charge for cold meat sandwiches.  We could have spend $40 at Panera and had more food and much higher quality.

It looks like this place is getting a lot of bad reviews lately.  I really hope they are reading their Yelp page and they fix things.  I will never go back here again.  I can eat at a nice steak house for $60.  Cold meat sandwiches aren't worth as much as this place charges for them.  Ripoff Central.  Stay away.

Sad face :(
No, wait. A GIANT SAD FACE :(

Why doesn't this birthday place have a better selection of cake? I'm a traditionalist, and I'd like to have a nice pice of layered cake on my birthday. My friend took me here on my b-day, and as soon as I saw the dessert menu, my heart started sinking .... . There was nothing I wanted to eat. Sigh. 

I ended up sharing a lame chocolate cake with him. Another sigh. 
I felt bad to be such a downer when someone was treating me .... but the cake really bummed me out!

I wish I could give this two different ratings. The atmosphere is over-the-top entertaining for kids (unless they have sensory issues, then it's gotta be pure torture). It's unique and crazy enough that I would give that part 3.5 stars. I'm pretty sure most kids would say it's a 5 star atmosphere, but they're not the ones paying the ridiculous prices, so their vote doesn't get as much credibility.

I do remember as a kid enjoying their ice cream and I think that's probably what it should stick with--ice cream. Not sure how many people order the "tongue," but I couldn't even bring myself to go with a burger and fries. My 6 year old and I split a serving of French toast (6 large slices in the one order). That was $7.99. The little tiny cup of strawberries to put on top was an extra $1.50 or was it $1.75? At least it was real recognizable fruit. The French toast was fine, but I prefer what we make at home. Thus, for the food (which grant it, wasn't a huge sample size) I would give it a 2. I am guessing their ice cream probably rates higher. 

Admittedly, I was quick to pull into the driveway when we happened to pass by it suddenly after a long day in Madison. I used to go here often as a kid (my mother must have been a saint) and wanted to share that experience with my own child. I guess 25+ years makes you forget a few things, like that the food isn't that great. C'est la vie.

The bathrooms during our visit were wet and muddy with trails of toilet paper on the floor, but thankfully weren't too nasty in other ways. The restaurant itself seemed clean enough. Our wait staff was courteous. Know that the outdoor carousel is a $1.00 a ride, although apparently if children are held on your lap  then the lap-rider is free.

Would I go back? Just on my own, no. With my child, probably for some ice cream and a carousel ride.

Some things never change. Ella's Deli is one of those things. 

I've been coming here with friends and family for more years than I care to mention. My grown daughter was pretty much prenatally raised on their food, as I was probably here weekly when I was carrying her. We have visited for nearly every family occasion of note ever since. 

The amazing thing is that the food has not changed one bit. I still order the same thing every time I visit, after all these years, and looking at the plate, I could not tell you if it was 2015 or (mumble-long-ago-year-mumble). There are a few new items, but not many. Beer and wine are a recent addition, but who goes to Disneyland and drinks? I dunno, I guess some people do, but I've never felt compelled to order alcohol here.

Most of the same robotic toy things are still in place, although many could use repair and a good dusting. (Poor Michael Jordan's arm is falling off, and the wizards are slumped over their magic acts like something went terribly awry in their performance.) Some of the same familiar staff faces are still there. They've changed from house made ice cream to Chocolate Shoppe, but nothing wrong with that. The prices have taken quite a jump, but I guess that is what it is. 

Our waitress was spectacular this weekend, even though she missed writing down lettuce for my sandwich, she didn't accuse me of not saying it, as seems to be the case for restaurant staff too often. She just brought me some., with zero attitude. Her bright smile and cheery demeanor was admirable in such a screamy-child environment. There was a hostess (tall, large blonde) that was going off on some customers, though, I'm not sure what her deal was. 

So, not a perfect experience, but for the most part super predictable and always fresh, quality, delicious food. Visitors to Madison with children should *not* miss it. Anyone who loves good deli food (and can tolerate shrieking for short periods of time) should also not miss it. Still a big fan.

By far the best kid friendly restaurant to take your kids. I live in the SF Bay Area now and my kids cannot wait to go back to Ella's Deli when we visit Madison to see Grandma and Grandpa. I wish we had one in Cali.

A hoarders paradise.  The food was OK, but I thought the ice cream was good.  Gaudy and too much SH**  everywhere.  We came here on a recommendation from someone in our group as a meeting place on our way to the Dells.  They have a huge menu, but NO Specialties.  I would imagine everything is frozen and cooked when you order it.  The tuna salad is made with Egg, which I have never seen before and did not like.  Not much of a micro beer selection (kind of expected), but they have Guinness, and two from New Glarus.  I will not be back, but I am sure some people will be.  Not my scene.

Great family entertainment, decent food.  Don't come here expecting a gourmet feast, it is for the kids.  Although, the reuben was good and the potato salad was also pretty good.  A little pricey, but you are paying for the atmosphere as well.  The carousel is only open in warm months  (whenever those are ;).

Very disappointed that they got rid of all their cool vintage candy and replaced it with dollar-store toys charging $10 per toy, RIGHT where everybody has to wait in line to pay for their food.  Seriously.  Nobody wants to pay the pretty penny to eat here only to have their experience end with having to choose between a disappointed child or an even-more-complete ripoff.

Absolutely not worth the money.  

To top it off, my youngest child thankfully wasn't into the toys and chose a lollipop that broke in her hand within seconds.  I could tell the clerk was almost going to say something to us when I replaced it with an unbroken one.  Really??  After we paid $30 for 3 ice creams, a bowl of soup, and a cheap toy????

We've been here several times.  Ella's is a pretty well known spot in Madison for NY style deli sandwiches/soups and ice cream.

The location is full of kitschy toy stuff, on the ceilings, on the walls and even inside the wooden tables where games can be played while your waiting for or eating your meal. The result of all the activity is that it is actually a noisy, clangy, plop-plop sounding place. Ella's is definitely targeting families with kids.

The location has a smaller version of an old-style carousel near the building, outside in the parking lot that brings back memories of days spent at Griffith Park in Los Angeles where it was a real thrill to ride the super-sized carousel.

The food here is AOK.  But, IMHO, this place is just about the experience, first, and the food, second.  Having said that, their hot sweet and sour cabbage soup with tidbits of beef is outstanding, as are their salads.

Ella's is an oddity but a child's haven.  It depends on why you're going here, if you're two grown adults and going to eat, the food is mediocre at best and very expensive. A plain as Jane tuna sandwich on regular bread is $10 and add an extra $3.25 for frozen krinkle cut fries. However, if you're a child, it's a sensory overload. The room is filled with wind up old toys, it's amazing. Even each table to dine at is decorated in toys, badger paraphernalia, clowns or something fun. The outdoor carousel is a must do. $1.50 and my niece screamed with joy! This place is great for some ice cream and to entertain a child.

I had fond memories of the Ella's Deli on State Street - and the fried pound cake in particular - and figured it would be a good second choice for brunch with my daughter when we found Monty's Blue Plate Diner was too busy on our visit to Madison.  What a mistake!  The restaurant itself is a kitschy tourist trap, with grime-covered mechanical toys littering the entire restaurant.  Entertaining for some perhaps, I found it extremely depressing.  The wait for our food seemed interminable, and when it did arrive, my omelet was cold, flat, and hardened.  I practically wanted to cry, realizing we had missed an opportunity for a wonderful breakfast at Monty's - much less, that we had shelled out as much as we had for a disgusting breakfast at Ella's.  I will not ever come back if I can help it.

DISGUSTING! 
I really want to just leave it at that, but that wouldn't be right. 
So let me tell you why I will never eat at Ella's again. 

For starters, it takes FOREVER until somebody comes over to seat you. Today I asked if I could sit in a booth, I wanted to pop out the laptop and needed some room to groove. I was walked over to the booths that line the one side of the restaurant and with the exception of the one that was occupied by a group of four, every single booth was overrun with dirty plates and glasses. Nothing says, "Come in, sit down, stay a while" like tables full of dirty shit. 

And so I was sat at a table. A table just a little too close to the server station, which is actually a server island. It's huge. And why? Stupid use of space. And a liiiiiiitle to visible. Today my lunch was punctuated by a dirty bus tub that stayed on the floor for mmmm 30 minutes before someone decided to pick it up and take it somewhere a bit more out of sight. And when she did, it was replaced by another bus tub, so servers could drop off more dirty shit instead of running it to the back. 

I won't go in to detail, it's not worth it, but suffice it to say it was rank. I almost lost it when a server dropped a few plates into the bin but sort of missed, making it so a smattering of fries blanketed the floor. Again, disgusting. 

I can't even comment on the food because my whole experience was tainted by the sight of ketchup smears, ice cream sundae remnants and those unruly stray fries. The only thing I kept thinking, "If this is their solution to clearing tables, I wonder what they think cleaning dishes means." 

Someone in Madison, please start making Matzo Ball soup. It's the only reason I went to Ella's but not even that is enough to get me to step foot in there after today. I would have to throw out the shoes I was wearing after and I have nice shoes.

Oh, Ella's, I feel like you used to be a lot better when I was younger. I can't specifically tell if the quality has decreased (though other recent reviews imply that may be the case) or if I've always been blinded by all the toys and the carousel, but this visit was just not as enchanting as all my previous visits over the years.

The surly teenager acting as host? Mmm yeah, maybe not the best face you want to be showing your customers when they walk into the door? Gosh, that kid was all grumps and monotone and unwelcoming. 

The food is a little drier than I remember it being. Why did you stop being a grease hole, Ella's? That was part of your thing! A Reuben on dry toast is not how I remember your Reubens. And why was my aunt's Reuben baked potato just a dried, baked potato with Reuben toppings? 

Your ice cream is still pretty good, so the next time I stop in I'll just get a shake and skip the solid food.

By far the worst restaurant I have been to in a long long while. The food was horribly over priced. The service was awful. The portions aren't worth 1/4 of what's paid even the water that we ordered came in a cup that was no more than 6 oz. The restaurant has so much going on with the atmosphere it ruined any value of conversation you could have. The food was awful. The ice cream was unoriginal which is all this place could have had to keep it some what worthy of my money. I will never return to this place and I do not suggest any of you do either.

If I had to sum up my meal in two words: odd brunch. I started the meal with a kugel & strawberries based on another yelper's review - ate almost the whole thing! Would def order it again or serve it for guests at a brunch. Yum. The matzo soup tasted OK, felt like it was surrounded by canned chix noodle (ala Cambell's) though. Entre was holishkes (bland cabbage rolls with chunky marinara sauce), the sides seemed like random afterthoughts and portion size was enormous. My daughter ordered the kid's mac & cheese with a side of applesauce (which is always served in a ridiculously tiny cup). The wait staff were friendly and accommodating. It can be overwhelming and claustrophobic on a busy night but Sunday night was as chill as it gets. Next time I'm sticking with my fave dish there: open-faced tuna melt. Can't go wrong there.

The menus just kill me... I have learned over the years how to navigate them quickly but seriously Restaurant Impossible needs to come in and revamp here! A simplified menu featuring well made dishes to compliment some home made ice cream would have an immediate positive impact. That and some cleaned up, contemporary, functioning decor would really breathe some life into this place! We'll never stop coming here but will enjoy it MUCH more with some improvements. I'm rooting for ya Ella's!
Not a great place for large groups. Went with my brother and his family, 10 of us total. It took TWO HOURS for sandwiches and ice cream. It used to be a great place.
Overpriced and blah food. Culver's makes better food than this. If you are expecting a great New York Deli experience, skip this.

if you have autism, stay the hell away from this place.  looks like mercer mayer blew up in there.  lots of ice cream and strange gadgets as far as the eye can see.  at night, the inside looks like a tool video.  very fun place if you are under ten.  or like ice cream.

I've been talking about this search for the perfect reuben for so long that people are starting to wonder. I figured that I'd better start documenting this search lest people begin to question my dedication to the task at hand.

I hadn't been to Ella's since I relocated to Madison 7yrs. ago. So I figured that this Madison Institution would be a good place to start. So, the sandwich was pretty decent. The corned beef was delicious and not too greasy. I don't know why they don't serve it on a dark rye, like most every other place I've had one (we'll forget the sourdough I had once in the north woods). Loss of points here. My only other gripe would be that they could have spared some fries and made a bigger sandwich.

The reason for the two star rating is the service I received. I was one of maybe four customers in the whole place (everyone else was already seated and eating when I arrived), and it still took ten minutes for a staffer to bring a cup of water. The server's demeanor was short and far from sweet.

So, bring the kids to Ella's. That's the demographic they're going for. It's like Chuck-E-Cheese for the pre-teen steampunk crowd. If you're looking for a decent reuben in Madison, get it to go.

As a Madison-area native for most of my life, taking a trip to Ella's Deli has always been a delight. As a kid I can remember going around the whole restaurant, investigating each table's theme and enjoying the toys flying overhead. That same atmosphere remains today, and it's a big reason why Ella's remains a go-to destination for my family (including my young son) today.

The menu is diverse, and you'll likely find something to your liking if you go in without knowing what's there. The basic foods are, well, basic -- don't expect a cheeseburger to be anything more than what it is -- but their specialties are well worth going back for.

With a carousel out in front, the fun toys and amusement inside, and a delicious menu to top it all off, you'll want to keep Ella's Deli in your repertoire for when friends visit from out of town. This staple of Madison dining isn't "fine dining," but it's enjoyable nonetheless.

Well, I will warn you: do NOT go here if you are currently tripping on anything. The crazy animatronic things everywhere will GET YOU. Also, screaming spawn and their usually smug breeder parents. On the plus side, they have great matzo ball soup and great blintzes. BLINTZES! Yes. So, if you have a kid, take them there at least once. They'll remember it for a long time. Also: word through the grapevine is that this place is not actually kosher.

This is the first place we take visitors when they come to Madison. We love to see the"shock and awe" on their faces when they see all the antique toys, flying puppets, games, carousels and other childhood delights crammed in cheek by Joel. It's a real Jewish deli, too. Very good food. They make the best matzo ball soup. We tried the blintzes as an appetizer because we were curious.  They were creamy, not too sweet and served with a choice of fruit preserves. I tried the holitchkes - stuffed cabbage rolls- and they were meaty and flavorful with a delicious tomato sauce on top. The only negative was that the cabbage was a little tough. The portions were very generous.

I got a visit in before this Madison treasure closes up on 1/21.  Me and a small group went for desserts.  There was a line out the door.  My wait was about 30 mins but we were okay waiting to have our good bye moment.

The wait staff were moving fast to clear tables as quick as folks left.  And they did it with smiles and grace.  They were generous with snapping pictures of the patrons and answering questions about the closing.  I was so impressed with their service.

One member of my party got the pasta and cheese.  It looked like a Velveeta cheese sauce over noodles but she liked it.  

Three of us ordered the Grilled Pound Cake Sundaes.  The fudge one was always my favorite.  One ordered a blueberry and she loved it.  The little one in our group ordered Superman Ice Cream served in a dish.  And one got Root Beer Float.  It came in a tall glass and looked fantastic.

We savored our treats.  Reminisced about past visits.  And we had a great last visit.  Thank you Ella's Deli for my fun childhood memories and being a nice place to come as an adult to remember those times.  You will be missed. 

If you go before they close, go with patience as there will be a line.  The business will close at 3pm on 1/21

LOVE THIS PLACE!  I grew up in Wisconsin, and this was a frequent visit with my parents.  It's a kids paradise!  Merry-go-round, fun food, ice cream, and the place is decorated with toys.  Something to look at everywhere.  Plus, you can buy candy buttons when you are leaving :0)

It's so sad to see this place going down the hole.

I have very fond childhood memories getting ice cream and riding the merry go round.

This last time might have been the last time. It was dirty, the staff is a whole other story, the place looked like it needed some serious TLC.

Note to whoever is the owner or in management, don't let an awesome nostalgic place like this fall due to you and your staffs laziness.

I ordered a French dip here for dinner the other night, and there was a very large brown insect right there on the plate, floating dead in the au jus.

They covered the price of our bill, at least. But it's still disgusting to think that their sanitation is lax enough that a bug can end up right on a customer's plate. Neat toys and animatronics aside, this place sorely needs a visit from the health inspector.

Amazing atmosphere, incredible food, friendly staff and a carousel.  We purposefully stopped on our drive from NC to MN and it was worth it.  Cheese curds, Kugel and blintzes - comfort food, fantastically wonderful comfort food. Take time to stroll around and look at all the incredible mechanical sights.  You can't but leave happy and full.

Was very busy the day we went and maybe they weren't prepared. Waited in line for 20 minutes and took an hour to get our food. Definitely not worth the wait. Reuben was just ok and fries cold. The fried dill pickle were the highlight. Great place to take the kids and look at all the cool toys but the food seems secondary.

Ella's Deli, an iconic restaurant here in Madison. I've been visiting this particular location on and off over the last 20 years or so. More so when our kids were younger, and when we lived just a few blocks away. The carousel of course has always been the main attraction and highlight. Even now, when it's open for the season, I, and my now teen/s still take advantage of a little ride once around. Now, about the inside atmosphere and food: yes, I won't deny it's a bit "gritty" so to speak. Sure, it could use some updating, but there's something nostalgic and kitschy about the original flooring, tables, counter tops. There's a lot of hoopla, movement, color, and mechanical paper mache characters moving above your head, that always seem to mesmerize youngsters, and a few elders I know as well. The food is, for the most part very good. It's one of these places I tend to order the same old, same old, because I'm never disappointed. I always loved the open face platters of turkey and gravy over mashed potatoes. The open face corned beef reuben on rye is always amazing and so is the sweet and sour cabbage soup. Mmmmmm.... love it. Fries are always yummy from my experience and the blue cheese burger is also good. I veered off my normal path recently and ordered the blueberry and blue cheese salad with walnuts. Loved it! The owners are very sweet people and take a lot of pride in their restaurant. I highly recommend stopping by when the weather is nice and the carousel is up and running. they keep the carousel and horses maintained and freshly painted often. I think they are doing right by keeping Ellas Deli up and running traditionally as most folks that come in, expect it to be as they remember it, and revel and reminisce in all that they always loved.

I've been longingly gazing at Ella's for years now every time I visit Madison. Now that I've finally moved here, I convinced my friends to pile in the car and give it a try! 

........REGRETS. 

First of all, what the nuts is going on inside?! So overstimulating. Then we were plopped down at a tacky table with an entire binder for a menu, with tabs separating all 599 meals they have, and the server didn't offer to explain anything. We were shocked at the prices, and served literally the worst meal I've ever paid for. My "Cheese Frank" was a cheap hot dog, in a bun that I'm assuming was leftover from 1942, with two half melted/half cold slices of kraft singles. 

We opted to skip desert, because who wants to pay $9 for a sundae after experiencing that "quality" of food for dinner?!

When I asked the hostess to split our bill, she looked utterly annoyed that I would inconvenience her on a dead wednesday evening, and  snakily complied. 

So so so so so so so so SOOOOO disappointed with my experience here. I won't ever go back, and I won't ever let my friends go back. YIKES.  I love food more than anything in this world, and that was not food. Don't waste your money or your time here.

Here's what I think: Once upon a time, this was an actual Jewish deli. Like maybe 40-80 years ago. Now? It's a midway for the kiddie rides. 

Here's what we waited 45 minutes: two orders of god-knows-how-old frozen crinkle fries, a grilled cheese that's exactly what a kid wants, only 35 minutes faster, and three blintzes from a box of frozen Empire blintzes, nearly burnt, with a thimbleful of applesauce. (The blintzes cost $10, btw, which makes them only about 4x what you'd pay at the supermarket.) The place is hot and sweaty and, yeah, kinda gross.

Took another forever to get the check. Would have gnawed a leg off to escape if I weren't already feeling crummy from the frozen blintzes. 

I bet if you're six and you go at 3 pm on a Thursday with your grandpa, it's awesome, just because of all the insane mechanical toys on the ceiling and the little carousel. But if you're not six or saintly, you should not go.

At the end of Back To The Future 3, creepy little Verne Brown signals and points to his crotch, when Doc is saying goodbye to Marty. No one knows why he did this. Well, a young girl was standing behind Marty. In fact, young Verne was known to do this and instead of moving to the next town like a logical person, Doc shifted his family from town to town in different time periods until the family landed in 1960's Madison. Verne was introduced to the "Hippie" lifestyle and soon changed his sex offender ways. Doc took this as an omen, he settled in and started a family restaurant. Ella's Deli was born.

I have an affinity for the creatively absurd, and only an absurd mind like Doc Brown's could have came up with such craziness. The decor is worth the price of a meal alone. Various cartoon characters from different generations float across the ceiling on motorized pulleys. Creepy clowns jump up and down on ledges. Pool balls travel along multiple tubes and contraptions across the entire ceiling. Each table had a diorama built inside of it. My 9 month old didn't stop looking around the whole time we were here.

Speaking of which, this might be the most family friendly restaurant I have ever been to. Along with the decor, there's a full size Merry Go Round outside of the place. The food is also very kid friendly, this is the first place I found with an "under 2 plate". Anyone with a kid who is just starting to eat knows how tough it is to go to a restaurant and try to share your food. They can only eat certain things, and everything has to be chopped up in little bits. Ella's makes this easy, putting yogurt, shaved turkey, crackers, peas and carrots, mandarin oranges, shredded cheese and applesauce on a tiny plate, charging us a little over 2 bucks. 

As far as the food goes, it's slightly above average. I had a Midwestern Burger, topped with a little horseradish sauce and big fried pickles. The burger was average, but the fried pickles were surprisingly good. My wife had the Garden burger which was good as well.

Dinner was pretty ho-hum, not bad but not the best. Then we had our socks knocked off with dessert. We shared a Turtle Grilled Poundcake Sundae, which was fantastic. We were fighting for spoonfuls, as the toppings were well balanced with the ice cream. So many times you get a turtle sundae and there is too much caramel or fudge, this one was perfect. I wanted to bring home some of the Poundcake to eat on its own (I wonder if they sell it to go? I should have asked).

This trip wasn't without its negatives. The actual food menu itself is unbelievably confusing, some of the items are listed twice in different parts of the menu, and it's pretty much hard to read. They should have someone clean it up. It took forever to be served. I know I came on Saturday during lunch, but we should be served a lot quicker than the over half hour we waited from putting in the order to be served our food.

Fun for all ages. I you haven't yet, you should dine here.

Been stopping here since the early 80's. The deli is kosher and I have'nt ate off the food menu for many years. Mom and I stopped here for a sundae as usual and the turtle sundae's are excellent! I had the poundcake turtle sundae and mom the regular turtle sundae as the poundcake has cinamon in it and she's allergic.

This place is a must stop on our roadtrips!

Lots of fun to look at.  There is so much random stuff around the ceiling and the walls and outside and behind the counter... you get the idea.  The menu is extensive.  The Rueben is alright.  I have had better.  But since there is so much more to try maybe something else is better.
Today had cream of potato soup and a bacon cheeseburger for lunch. Can't imagine how it could be better.  Clean operation with courteous help, good food and fair prices.

This place used to be amazing. Now it sucks. The food is awful. The desserts are awful. The service is awful. I went twice recently just to give it a second chance but it was still bad. Even the decorations are falling apart/not moving anymore. The ONLY thing worth getting still is the matzo ball soup and maybe the fried pickles. 
Breaks my heart, they should call Robert Irvine or Gordon Ramsey.

The environment was fun and exciting for our two little kids. However the sloooow service really brought down my rating of it. Expect to be there for a while even when they're not busy. Food was good, but not worth the price you'll pay for it. It was a fun place for the kids to go to, but not sure I'll be back anytime soon.
Overpriced. Emailed owners twice to ask if they had vegan options and they ignored my emails. Seems like it used to be nice but has gone downhill.

I miss Ella's Deli. There was just something so magical about it. 

Maybe it's my memories of riding the carousel as a child. Maybe it's the whimsical decorations that filled the interior. Maybe it's just this idea I've had in my brain about what Ella's is - was - since I was very young. 

The food was never outstanding, but it wasn't bad either! I always had good service. The ice cream was fantastic. 

I can't honestly think of a bad thing to say about Ella's Deli. It's a place that I wish Madison was able to keep going forever. There will never be another like it.
